Dear Prime Minister,
I am writing to inform you of my Government's views on how best to progress the implementation of the National Forest Policy Statement (NFPS).

As you are aware, the NFPS acknowledges the importance of a comprehensive, adequate and representative network of dedicated and secure nature conservation reserves for forests and reserves for the protection of forested wilderness. The signatory Governments have agreed to review the appropriateness of the existing reserve system and determine whether any further action is required to complete its development.

As part of this commitment, the Governments have agreed to a strategy to ensure the existence of a comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system for areas of old growth forests and forested wilderness ("the CAR reserve system").

As the first step in this, data needs to be collected and assessments made on the old growth and wilderness values of forests. In accordance with the provisions of the NFPS, the assessments are to commence after Governments have reached agreement on reserve assessment criteria.

The NFPS also provides for a comprehensive regional assessment process for forested areas involving the collection and evaluation of information on environmental and heritage aspects of forests in a region ("the CRA process"). This process would provide the basis for a regional agreement relating to Commonwealth and State obligations for forests in that region.

The NFPS does not explicitly provide that the review of the CAR reserve system and the CRA process be jointly progressed. However, in order to reduce duplication and uncertainty, it would clearly be sensible for this to occur. This joint procedure should involve the following steps:
to begin, data collection activities for the purposes of reviewing the CAR reserve system would proceed jointly with data collection for the CRA process;

PARA.TAB: .next, this data would be evaluated for purpose of the CRA process—part of this evaluation would be the assessment of values of old growth forests and forested wilderness to review the CAR reserve system;
.the CRA process would then produce an intergovernmental regional agreement including, inter alia, decisions on the CAR reserve system.

INTERJECT.PARA: I have already written to you on the need for socio-economic considerations to be taken into account in the review of the CAR reserve system. Under the National Ecologically Sustainable Development Strategy, our Governments agreed that all values, including environmental and socio-economic values, must be effectively integrated into decision-making on land and resource use.

I am, however, concerned that the CRA process as provided for under the NFPS appears to be limited to environmental and heritage values and does not incorporate socio-economic values. This would make it difficult for the ensuing agreement to accommodate all Government obligations, such as obligations relating to regional employment and investment. Accordingly, the CRA process in its totality, and not just that component relating to the review of the CAR reserve system, must explicitly incorporate socio-economic considerations.
As already mentioned, the first action in implementing the above is the collection of data on all values of forests on a regional basis.

You are aware that my Government has established the Natural Resources Audit Council (NRAC) to collect information on all of the values of public land and natural resources on a regional basis. This information will assist the Government in making land and resource use and allocation decisions, including decisions relating to forests.

NRAC is therefore well placed to be the State's data collection agency for the purposes of the CRA process, including coordinating data collection activities for old growth and forested wilderness for the review of the CAR reserve system.

In my letter of 16 September, I invited the Commonwealth to participate in the development of the regional data collection procedures to be followed by NRAC. It is hoped that this will facilitate the accommodation within those procedures of Commonwealth responsibilities, including obligations relating to forests, from the outset.

Indeed, in the interests of ensuring that Commonwealth responsibilities are met, my Government has requested the Commonwealth to accredit NRAC's processes under the Intergovernmental Agreement on the Environment.

I have given NRAC, as its first reference for a Regional Audit, the Upper North East of New South Wales. As part of its Audit, NRAC will collect information on all of the values of forested public land. This will include the coordination by NRAC of data collection on the old growth and wilderness values of forests on public lands in the region.

The data collected by NRAC could form the basis of assessments of values of old growth forests and forested wilderness for the Upper North East region for the purposes of the CRA process. As outlined above, those assessments would be used for, amongst other things, decisions on the review of the CAR reserve system in the region.

This sequence of events—whereby NRAC collects data, which is then input into the old growth and wilderness assessments for the CRA process, which then result in decisions on the CAR reserve system—would occur first in the forests in the Upper North East region of New South Wales. This is appropriate, given that the greatest need for forest data exists in that region. This sequence of events would be repeated across the State as NRAC progressively conducts further Regional Audits.

Of course, the assessments and decisions for the purposes of the review of the CAR reserve system will not be able to be made until the reserve assessment criteria are agreed by Governments. Nevertheless, some data collection activities for the Upper North East region can proceed immediately, to feed into the NRAC Regional Audit and to advance the objectives of the NFPS.

I understand from your previous correspondence that the Commonwealth has offered funds to NSW to carry out data collection activities as required under the NFPS. I have directed the relevant State agencies to now apply for those funds, to be used initially in the Upper North East as part of NRAC's first Regional Audit.

I anticipate that some of the funds will be used to finance surveys of the old growth values of the North East forests. These surveys will further refine and verify the methodology developed by the Victorian Department of Conservation and Natural Resources to identify and delineate old growth forests.

Finally, I wish to draw your attention to provisions in the NFPS which require Governments to take interim measures to "avoid activities that may significantly affect those areas of old growth forest or wilderness that are likely to have high conservation value." These interim measures would remain in place until the completion of the assessment of forests for conservation values, which, as discussed earlier, should proceed in conjunction with the CRA process.

As you are aware, the NSW Government has already halted logging in specified areas of old growth forest under the Timber Industry (Interim Protection) Act 1991. This Act places an interim moratorium on logging in old growth forests identified in the Government's 1990 Old Growth Forest Strategy pending the completion and determination by the Minister for Planning of environmental impact statements (EIS) under the Environmental Planning and Assessment Act 1979.

The Timber Industry (Interim Protection) Act also excludes logging from wilderness nominations which had not previously been the subject of an EIS. The Government is currently involved in the consideration of a number of wilderness nominations under the Wilderness Act 1987.

It should be remembered that the NFPS provides that "Australia will continue to use old growth timber for many years". The Statement represents an attempt to balance forest conservation and development considerations in accordance with the principles of Ecologically Sustainable Development. Indeed, as your own Ministers Cook and Evans have now acknowledged, the NFPS was never meant to impose a moratorium on logging in all old growth forests and forested wilderness areas.

My Government will continue to avoid logging activities in certain old growth forests and forested wilderness areas which are likely to have high conservation value pending the completion of assessments of forests for conservation values.
I trust that the above clarifies the NSW Government's views regarding implementation of the NFPS.
Yours sincerely

REGIONAL FORESTS AGREEMENTS
The Associate Secretary of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, Roger Beale, recently sent me a copy of the paper "Regional Forests Agreements—A Commonwealth Position".

After considering the paper I have concluded that at both Commonwealth and State levels we need to revisit the objectives of the National Forests Policy Statement. My recollection is that the concept of comprehensive regional assessment and regional agreements was based on the desire to reduce fragmentation and duplication in the land use decision making process, and to achieve agreed and durable land use decisions so that the community obtains a balanced return from all forest uses.

With these objectives in mind I was greatly concerned at the proposed process for arriving at an agreed position on forest management and use. It appears to be extremely complex, open-ended, and resource-intensive. In addition, the scope and nature of Commonwealth involvement are not well defined, particularly in relation to the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) legislation. As you and I well know, an intergovernmental committee is an unwieldy mechanism, and would be unlikely to reach agreement on the interpretation of the assessments demanded by the process, let alone successfully negotiate the intergovernmental agreement along with the detailed forest management guidelines and plans. The process would never end.

Implicit in the proposal would seem to be a requirement that Victoria re-visit many of the processes and procedures that are either on-going including old-growth studies and forest management planning or which have been completed for the foreseeable future such as the identification of regional sustained yields or public land use decisions following assessment by the Land Conservation Council (LCC). This would be an example of the very duplication of effort which I understood we were trying to avoid.

You will recall that I wrote in September last year (copy attached) expressing concern that commitments by our two Governments to co-operate in natural resource use planning may be failing to produce worthwhile results. In particular I formally requested:

an identification of specific gaps, if any, in the joint work being carried out in Victoria's Central Highlands forests, in terms of its adequacy for the Commonwealth to come to a firm determination on use of those forests; and

the Commonwealth's criteria for accreditation under the Inter-Governmental Agreement on the Environment along with a summary of where, if at all, Victoria's Land Conservation Council (LCC) process is considered to fall short.

I am still waiting for a response on these two points. I am aware that at the recent meeting of the Intergovernmental Committee on Ecologically Sustainable Development on 30 March a very preliminary paper on the Commonwealth's proposed approach to accreditation was discussed, however, I understand that there was little real progress on the issue.

In my view consideration of a process for achieving Regional Forest Agreements would be assisted if we could see what the implications were in practice. I suggest that to get a practical focus both the Commonwealth and Victorian Governments commit to an attempt to reach agreement on forest management and use in the Victorian Central Highlands.

As a first step Victoria and the Commonwealth should move to solve any outstanding issues with respect to accreditation of the LCC process so that the work done for the Melbourne Area 2 studies can be taken into account. In my assessment the LCC process meets the Commonwealth broad criteria as presented in their recent paper. Therefore the Commonwealth should, as I suggested in my earlier letter, specifically identify any deficiencies in the LCC processes so Victoria can consider how these might be overcome. Any extra work is needed in the region over and above that already done by the LCC and the Australian Heritage Commission should then be specified and completed so that negotiation of the Regional Agreement can proceed.

With respect to the Forest Management Plans, I would like to suggest that detailed management plans be prepared by officials experienced in this work in the Victorian Department of Conservation and Natural Resources once the broad terms of the Regional Agreement are settled. Commonwealth officials would then be given the opportunity to make comment and negotiate amendments if the plans do not meet Commonwealth requirements. A time limit not in excess of six months should be set for negotiating this final agreement with the Commonwealth.

I believe that unless an attempt is made to actually finalise an agreement, discussions will continue at the non-specific level and we will make no progress on an issue of fundamental importance to this nation.
Yours sincerely

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Trade with United States of America

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. The United States of America is the world's largest economy and has traditionally been and remains a critically important market for Australian exporters. In 1993-94 the United States represented our second largest export market, after Japan, with exports totalling $5 billion. From weekend reports I understand that you, Minister, have initiated a study of our trading relationships with the United States. What is the purpose of this review, and when do you expect to receive the report?

—I thank Senator McKiernan for the question. It is true that on Friday I announced a review of Australia's trading relationship with the United States for the purpose of examining what scope there is to lift our trade performance in the United States. There is an apparent deterioration of our trade performance in relation to the US, and it is important that we address it.

PARA.TAB: As Senator McKiernan said, the US is and remains the world's single largest import market. Imports have been growing at the rate of about 7.3 per cent per annum over the past decade. It is a market offering immense opportunities for Australia, and there are some areas in which we are succeeding quite well. We do not want, in looking at the overall picture, to lose sight of the successes. Our services exports to the United States are growing. Other important areas, such as computer equipment sales, seem to be increasing quite strongly.

Over the three years of 1991, 1992 and 1993, our exports to the US fell. That exacerbated the trade deficit that we have always had with the US to the point where, in 1993-94, our trade deficit was $9 billion—obviously, a very substantial proportion of the deficit for that year.

There are some critical questions that we need to address. What can we do to address this situation? What do we need to do to strengthen our trade performance there? We need to look at the pattern of investment as well as trade. Overwhelmingly, we need to look at what we can do better to improve our performance in the United States—that is No. 1.

We will also address the barriers to Australia's trade with the United States. The United States, like Australia, is mainly an open market, but there are some barriers that continue and they affect our exporters directly. We want to look at that in the context of that deficit. We also want to look at the international trade policies of the United States and the implications they have for our trading position.

Some of their international trade activities are substantially to Australia's benefit and we need to realise that, as well as address those which are to our disadvantage—some of which have had publicity recently. We are going to try to do a balanced review, try not to blame others for things that are of our making, look at our own performance and address some of the broader structural questions.

There are a range of possible reasons for the decline in our share of the US market, and they are not necessarily all problems. It may be caused by the fact that we are running into capacity constraints because of the diversion of trade to the Asian market. Our exports overall might not be falling. It may be—

TALK.START.PARA: —But we are falling behind in the Asian market, too.

—That is not actually right. You keep asserting it, but it is not right. We have to look at our overall trade position. From 1973 to 1983, our market share globally fell significantly; we fell from 12th to 22nd. From 1983 to 1993, we maintained that relative position. Our share of world exports and our relative position in world exports have been the same in the last decade. So we are doing well in some markets and badly in others. Clearly, it is not—
—You didn't improve it, then.

—We have reversed the decline which we were left with, but we have not improved it and we need to do more. There may be some shifting to more profitable markets by our private sector, and that is a perfectly rational thing for them to do. With all the time that we have put into building new markets, we need also to address our traditional markets. I hope to have a working draft of the review by March of this year, following which we will have close consultations with business and the unions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before getting into the detail of this question, let me make it clear what the purpose of this grant was. I was challenging the conservation organisations to provide substantiated evidence about their claims of the conservation values of forest areas. I did not want unsubstantiated advice that had been made available in previous years around the time of the licence renewal process.

PARA.TAB: I agreed to provide them with funding to ensure that the information they provided was of the highest possibly quality. The advice they provided was an input—and only one of a number of inputs—into the preparation of my portfolio's advice to Minister Beddall. The grants were made from a departmental program dedicated to the implementation of the NFPS. It was stressed to the conservation groups that, whoever the conservation councils engaged in their work on this exercise, they must have the appropriate skills and that close cooperation must be maintained with the department to ensure that the public moneys were fully accounted for.

As I indicated before, the conservation organisations were required to sign an agreement setting out the terms and conditions of the grant. The agreement, which was signed by the Tasmanian Conservation Trust, the Nature Conservation Council of New South Wales, Environment Victoria and the Conservation Council of Western Australia, required the conservation organisations to produce three reports—an informal progress report, a draft final report and a final report. Those conditions were met. The conservation groups were asked to give priority to identifying old-growth forest and wilderness areas likely to be of high conservation value and likely to require interim protection.

In terms of the methodology, in the course of undertaking the grant the people contracted by the conservation organisations met with officers of my portfolio on the three occasions I mentioned. The methodology was set in the first meeting, with reports by the conservation councils on old-growth forests, wilderness, rainforest, endangered species, biodiversity and cultural values. The methodologies focused on the definitions used in the NFPS and the methods state agencies had used at various times to map those values.

The second meeting continued the discussion on the methodologies and thresholds to be used in examining old-growth forests and wilderness and discussed the level of substantiation that my portfolio would require. That meeting was followed by meetings with the individual state conservation councils.

A third meeting was held to discuss the draft reports prepared by the conservation councils and for portfolio officers to discuss in detail comments on those reports. The department had a legal grant agreement with the conservation councils and not with individuals. The contribution of individuals to the council reports would have varied substantially. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, are you now telling us that you did not really seek assessments from these people even though that is what they purported to offer you; that you merely sought advice as one of a range of inputs? I ask you again: will you provide the Senate with detailed written evidence of the criteria that you asked for? Will you also give us the details of the methodology that they were to adopt and in fact adopted, or are you simply telling us that all this is on some metaphorical, biodegradable whiteboard in the sky that has disappeared and you have no evidence at all to justify handing out a couple of hundred thousand dollars of taxpayers' money to buy a result you wanted in advance?
—I have described that the input of the conservation councils was one input in this particular process. It was also a process coordinated by the portfolio.

—On a point of order, my question was: are these no longer assessments made but simply advice sought from a range of groups? —Order! There is no point of order.

—I have indicated all along what the process was and how the matter was coordinated by the forest branch of my portfolio. —A woodchipping question, Shayne?

—I know where all the logs are—over there! My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology. On Friday last you announced the winners of the Australia Prize, which is awarded to scientists for their contribution to human welfare. Could the minister explain to the Senate the role and the importance of the Australia Prize in the government's strategy to develop Australian science.

—I know Senator Murphy does have, unlike some people on the opposition side, a very keen interest in Australian science and is one of the more articulate people who speak on that subject in this chamber. The Australia Prize is a major international award which is increasingly gathering world prestige as a major event on the annual science calendar. It is valued at $A300,000 and attracts entries from all over the globe. It recognises, as has been said, outstanding achievements—
—Why don't you put the money into Australian science?
—It goes into the importance of Australian science.
—No, it doesn't.

—If you want to talk about the subject and you are the opposition spokesman, you should break your duck and ask a question about science for the first time in your shadow ministerial life in this chamber. The award is worth $300,000 and recognises major outstanding achievements in science through research that benefits humanity.

PARA.TAB: The award is genuinely of international stature. Last year Professor Gene Likens, an American pioneering ecologist, won the award. The Sydney Morning Herald referred to him as one of those scientists who had discovered the important links that cause acid rain in the world and it referred to the award as being the Australian equivalent of the Nobel Prize.

I was privileged to announce on Friday that the award had been won this year by three Australians and one American in the category of remote sensing. The Australians are Dr Ken McCracken, Dr Andrew Green and Dr Jonathan Huntington—all previously or currently with the CSIRO and all world leading authorities on this important subject. The American is Professor Richard Moore, who has also been working in this field.

The Australia Prize was inaugurated by my predecessor as science minister, Barry Jones, in 1990. It ensures that Australia captures global science attention for the awarding of the prize and for the standard of the contributions. When Australian scientists win the award, that projects their reputation and our image as a nation doing good science globally. That is an important element of the prize, and it is widely supported in the Australian science community.

It is the Australian government's intention to ensure that Australia's high reputation around the world for science and as a site of much original knowledge in the field of science—we produce original knowledge at a level much higher than our population or economy would suggest; we are valued at the world scientific table as an important contributor—is expanded and that we build on the status we have already achieved. In the last budget, the Commonwealth government spent $3.2 billion on science and research. In comparing us with the opposition when it was in government, if one can remember that far back, the amount of outlays as a proportion of the total budget outlays going to science has increased under this Australian Labor government.

I commend to the Senate the eminent scientists, particularly the Australians, who have won the Australia Prize this year. It is a cause for national celebration. It will ensure that our reputation in the science community worldwide is upheld.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Finance. I refer him to the comments made yesterday by the finance minister that the government's approach to this year's budget would be to get the structure very highly focused and politically able to be explained sensibly to the Australian people. He then went on to say, `We can't willy-nilly decide it off the top of our heads, because these days you have to get a total package together.' Is the minister confirming that the 1993 and 1994 budgets, unlike the upcoming budget, were focused, sensible and interlocked? Is this something new to this government? Is he confirming the failure of his past approach to budget framing? Will this year's budget include genuine long-term measures and planning, or are we in for another ad hoc string of measures like the disastrous approach to the timber industry, whereby there will be a whole rope with a lot of kites flying on them, as we have seen this week?

—I can confirm reports that the budget for the year 1995-96, which the government is now just giving its mind to, will be a responsible, visionary and long-term budget. It will be the most appropriate budget for Australia in the circumstances.

PARA.TAB: I am aware that the Minister for Finance, in an interview on the Sunday program, was invited to make some comment about whether or not the budget would be able to be got through the Senate. In that context, he made some remarks. I should say that it has always been the intention of the government—it has been typified by our performance in previous budgets—to frame the most appropriate budget. It has sometimes been the case that measures in the budget are resisted in this chamber. Ruminating out aloud, as he was on that program, the Minister for Finance threw up some ideas about how this might be best dealt with in the current climate. I might underline that this climate is exampled by the disgraceful behaviour of the opposition in saying prior to a budget coming down that if there are any changes to taxation in that budget it will prevent the government from governing and resist such a budget measure in this chamber. That is a disgraceful example of opportunism. As the Minister for Finance said on the Sunday program, it is an example of a party that does not know the meaning of the terms `stable' or `long-term' and a party that has had three leaders in eight months. It is into resisting rather than thinking about alternative means of governing and presenting a coherent alternative economic package to the community.

As I understand it, it is the intention of the finance minister and the Treasurer to engage in proper and considered consultations with the minor parties. It is my understanding that in March the major parameters of the budget will be released, as they were last year, and that consultations will follow in an appropriate way. I therefore hope that when we bend our mind to the final framing of the budget this chamber will be one not of obstruction but of enlightenment which ensures that the budget is carried.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister says that the government's intention is to frame the most appropriate budget. Is that appropriate fiscally or politically? Can the minister confirm that the starting point for the framework will be the merit and the equity of the proposals rather than how the government can get itself out of the sorts of corners that it has painted itself into in the least unpalatable way?

—I detect a note of ready cynicism in Senator Kernot's question. It has always been the view of this government that sound and good economics is sound and good politics. Those who play the short-term political games which the opposition is playing, those who try to engage in political or economic stunts, those who hold up symbols, who always oppose and who are never responsible, will suffer the wrath of what is increasingly a highly literate, in economic terms, Australian electorate.

PARA.TAB: Our policy perceptions will be along the lines of what is the most appropriate response given the nature of the Australian economy as it is now and along the lines of the tradition of the Labor Party to ensure proper equity for the citizens of this society and to give appropriate attention to those who need government support and assistance.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. In the light of the government's round table discussion on climate change which will be held tomorrow and acknowledging the growing scientific consensus about the disastrous impact of greenhouse emissions on the global climate, I ask: could the minister explain how he would anticipate a carbon levy operating and can he give an assurance that the funds obtained from such a levy would be offset against programs to reduce greenhouse emissions? Does the minister agree that a properly implemented carbon levy could complement both a no regrets policy and an integrated legislative and policy framework on greenhouse emissions? Can the minister give us an assurance that there will be real and effective measures to significantly reduce greenhouse gas emissions in this country?

—I am pleased that Senator Margetts is aware of the consultation process the government is holding on the climate change issue. The government is having two ministerial round tables which will comprise key stakeholders from both industry and consumer and conservation organisations. These consultations follow on from a series of bilateral meetings that have taken place between interested departments and key stakeholder groups.

PARA.TAB: The intention is to give the stakeholders input to the range of policy measures which the government could consider implementing to enhance our response to the level of greenhouse gas emissions. The consultations in themselves are a significant indication of the government's intention to develop a serious response to the challenge of the level of greenhouse gas emissions, which is a very serious global environmental problem. The process follows Cabinet's reaffirmation in December of the need for an effective and ongoing response to climate change and a clear message from the national greenhouse inventory that with our current enhanced greenhouse measures Australia would not meet its targets.

Specifically in response to the second part of Senator Margetts's question, as the government considers options and discuses them with interest groups, a properly implemented small greenhouse levy could be considered as part of a broad ranging integrated package of measures. She asked the hypothetical question: could it complement a no regrets policy? That could be the case as part of an integrated policy framework, as I believe Senator Margetts knows.

In relation to the third part of the question, the government is committed to an effective set of greenhouse response measures. Obviously we are committed to reducing the level of greenhouse gas emissions in Australia and we intend to continue our commitment to consult with those others in the Australian community who have a genuine interest and involvement in this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —One aspect of that question was not answered; so I will seek to get a response to that, at least. Could the minister assure us that the funds obtained from any such levy we would require would be offset against programs to reduce greenhouse emissions?

—We do not have such a levy and it is not my intention to answer hypothetical questions like that. Senator Margetts has asked a number of hypothetical questions, but it would be improper for me to answer them in that form.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. Minister, last Thursday you stated in the Senate that there was no truth in the claim that a deal was done with the Tasmanian Labor Party which resulted in about 50 Tasmanian forest coupes being removed from your department's list of 511 and being replaced at the last minute with 50 in East Gippsland in Victoria. Was the Tasmanian Labor forest spokesman Paul Lennon, a close associate of Senators Murphy and Sherry, therefore lying when he claimed that his eleventh hour efforts had resulted in the number of Tasmanian coupes on your list being lowered by 50? I have a copy of his press release here. Do you also deny that at the very last minute an additional 50 or so coupes were added to your list for East Gippsland?

—I cannot give you any more information to that I gave last week. I indicated clearly that there was no truth to an allegation contained in a question from the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Hill. I cannot add any more to that. If you wish, obviously you can ask Mr Lennon or anyone else who is involved.
—Should we ask Bob Collins?

—You can do that too, if you like, Senator, but I am quite sure that you will receive the same answer that you have received from me. I can say to you that the refinement of the list of Tasmanian coupes identified as likely to have high conservation value has resulted in a list of 72 coupes scheduled for harvesting operations this year. These include coupes containing old-growth forest, significant wilderness values, or perhaps both attributes; those coupes that may be adjacent to Tasmanian world heritage areas and where further forestry operations are likely to have an impact or cause a diminution of world heritage values or facilitate the impact of other threatening processes; and also coupes within or immediately adjacent to areas on the register of the national estate with continued forestry operations likely to result in adverse effects and impacts on national estate values.

—Minister, I remind you that your publicly released list of 511 coupes includes 95 from East Gippsland. How do you explain the fact that a Victorian forest company was notified by an officer of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy on the day of the Prime Minister's 27 January announcement and, presumably, based on your department's list of 511 coupes, that only 50 in East Gippsland were to be set aside?

—I cannot answer questions that go to officers of state departments. I do not think any fair- or reasonable-minded person could ask me to speculate on what an officer of the department of primary industry in Victoria has said. That is a most extraordinary question, and I do not intend to speculate on the answer.

—I address my question to the Minister for Family Services. Yesterday there were reports in the media that the New South Wales government is planning to sign the national child-care strategy. Why has it taken the New South Wales government four years to apparently agree to sign that strategy? What is the federal government's response to those reports?
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. The question asks Senator Crowley why the New South Wales government did not do something. Surely that is not within Senator Crowley's portfolio.
—Mr President, on the point of order: I also asked for the federal government's response to the media comments, and that is in order.
—The question is in order.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I ask that you rule out of order that part of the question which relates entirely to the New South Wales government and rule in order the last part of the question.
—Questions are frequently asked about government policy and then reflect on opposition policy or the opposition policies of other states. It is perfectly in order, and it is often asked in that way.

—Mr President, on the point of order: how on earth could Senator Crowley, a minister of the federal government, know what was the intent or in the mind of a state government? The question is clearly out of order, and I ask you to rule it out of order.
—I have already made my ruling.

—Let me say by way of answer that I was very surprised to read in the paper that the New South Wales government is planning to sign the national child-care strategy. It certainly has not contacted me yet, if ever, and over the last four years it has resisted all efforts by the Commonwealth government to sign that strategy. So one has to wonder very much about why it is now, six weeks from an election, that the New South Wales government has decided it will sign the strategy. As I say, I have not had any approach from the minister.
—Are you pleased they are going to sign it?

—I will wait and see what the proposal is from New South Wales. I would be delighted if it had signed and/or will sign because the people of New South Wales have been missing out on child-care places for the last four years. I think what is particularly interesting is the timing of this announcement. While Rocky Gattellari was discrediting the opposition in the eyes of people in New South Wales, particularly the women—
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. What could Rocky Gattellari have to do with the question that was asked?
—Senator Crowley, I ask you to get to the point of the question.

—The point is that here is a government that is in jeopardy due to its attitude to women by way of one of its members or endorsed candidates. At the same time, it has suddenly decided to announce something that will be winning for women. Women in New South Wales have been campaigning for a child-care strategy for a long time. I would have thought, Senator Hill, that without much trouble at all you could draw your own conclusions about the association of those two events.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order with regard to relevance. That is highly speculative nonsense. Why doesn't the minister get up and account for her own portfolio and her own performance? That is what she is here for; that is what question time is supposed to be about.

—Mr President, on the point of order: it is getting a bit spurious on the other side at the moment. Those opposite are a bit precious. They demand answers to questions from their side that go to state administrations, but they refuse to allow Senator Crowley to answer a question that goes very much to the administration of federal policy and federal programs. That is precisely what this question is about, and she has full right to do so without this sort of harassment from the other side.
—I have already ruled that that is the case, but I have asked Senator Crowley to address her points to the question directly and to keep as close as possible to her policy area.

—I am very interested to see and I look forward to any letter from New South Wales. As I say, for the last four years—certainly the last two years that I have been in this portfolio—we have been seeking very actively to persuade the New South Wales government to sign the child-care strategy because we know from an exchange of correspondence that the New South Wales government has not been minded, until now, to sign that strategy.

PARA.TAB: The people of New South Wales have missed out on child-care places and, although I did not hear it, I was advised that Mr Longley, the Minister for Community Services, said today that he has been able to win a better deal for the people of New South Wales. That is only if and when I have seen it and it is agreed to. On the facts provided to me, it is not true. He is skewing the figures. The people of New South Wales have been dudded of about 3,500 long day care child places and many more outside school hours places. All of you over there know that because you keep writing me letters saying, `Please, what can you do to help establish child care in New South Wales?' Indeed, the last two letters I got were from both Minister Longley and Minister Chikarovski writing to me to ask about child-care places. They should look to their own nest. They should have been persuading Premier Fahey to sign that agreement and to get those child-care places up. I sincerely hope the people of New South Wales are not fooled by this cynical, opportunistic announcement.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Minchin Sen N.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Family Services, Senator Crowley. When you introduced the child-care rebate, you attacked the coalition for suggesting that it should be means tested. Yesterday's Sunday Mail reported one of your ministerial colleagues as saying:

QUESTION.PARA: Some slackness has crept into the system and allowing people who earn a million dollars a year to claim for their childcare is a luxury we can no longer afford.
Also, the ACTU president, Martin Ferguson, said:
Frankly, millionaires don't need childcare assistance or maternity payments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Those things were very aptly described in earlier times by Senator Kernot as `a long rope with a lot of kites flying on the back of it.' It is people postulating what might possibly be in the budget. As you over there know, particularly Senator Minchin, I am not about to comment on any speculation that might be associated with the budget.
—No, your policy and your government's policy.

—My policy and the government's policy is quite clear and it is what you voted for when it came into this place. Do not get uppity now, Senator Hill or Senator Minchin. You supported that policy when it came into this place. You know that very well.

PARA.TAB: This policy is part of this government's comprehensive programs for families. We have increased child-care places from 46,000 to 250,000; we have made them affordable with our child-care assistance, and we have added to that affordability with the child-care cash rebate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. Senator Crowley was asked a specific question: to confirm her government's policy. She should not be allowed to elaborate on policy generally.
—Her answer is relevant in general terms. There is no point of order.

—I conclude by saying that our child-care policies have been part of a considerable program of support for families. Child care is critically and centrally part of that, Senator Troeth, as you well know. We have also been concerned to target our payments and assistance, particularly to those at the lower end of the income scale.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order on relevance as well. Senator Crowley was really asked about the election bribe: to offer child-care rebates to all Australians—to hand out money to billionaires and to anybody else after the election. Now that the budget is in trouble, we find ministers coming out and saying, `We made an error.' That is what she was asked about, not the total package, not wanting to care. The whole point is that the government is giving money to those who do not need its help. That is what you are being asked about.
—There was no point of order, but that was a good opportunity for a statement.

—I simply conclude my answer by reminding honourable senators that the policy on the child-care cash rebate is something they all voted for. So if we want to stick with the child-care cash rebate and not expand wider than that, Senator Hill, examine your own view on this matter. We have been concerned about keeping child care affordable. That is our main intent and that is what we will continue to do.

—Minister, why don't you simply admit that you were wrong not to means test the child-care rebate in the first place, particularly given the harsh income test on the home child-care allowance, and that you are about to be humiliated by the cabinet?
—Why don't you admit you were wrong in supporting Alexander Downer?

—Thank you very much, Senator McMullan; that was a good reply. That is an absolutely ridiculous question. I am certainly not about to admit that I am wrong, particularly when you supported it, as I remind you again. That child-care cash rebate was part of our labour market programs and recognition of the importance of child care to enable families to participate in the work force. It is part of a comprehensive package. Although Senator Troeth may say that I was trawling across policy, our policies on child care are comprehensive. You cannot talk about one without talking about them all. We want places; we want quality places; we want affordable places. They are our policies in this area and that is what we will continue.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Resources. Is it true that 60 per cent of Australia's timber requirements derive from plantations? What is the quantity and value of the timber which Australia imports? By how much would existing plantations need to be expanded to replace Australia's timber imports? What has the government done to encourage that plantation expansion and what will the government do to ensure that such expansion continues?

—I will be brief. With relevance to this question, I think Senator Bell would agree that you cannot quantify this material by simply describing all of it as timber. I am sure Senator Bell knows that the question of whether it is softwood or hardwood and the use to which the timber is put is an extremely important consideration about whether plantations—

PARA.TAB: Senator Kernot interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —As you well know, plantations in Australia are almost all softwood timber. The industry only in recent years has started to develop extensively plantation timber with hardwood. About 33,000 hectares of plantation a year are now being planted in Australia. The plantations currently cover about a million hectares. In fact, I think it has exceeded that figure now. Eighty-eight per cent of the current plantation timber is softwood and only about 12 per cent is hardwood. We produce about 77 per cent of our own sawn timber needs in Australia and we produce all of our woodchip requirements in Australia. Softwood plantations supply 55 per cent of domestic production of sawn timber and native forests supply approximately 45 per cent. Australia's existing plantation resource is presently insufficient to supply all of our sawn timber requirements on a sustainable basis.

PARA.TAB: I notice that in recent times a well-known identity in the timber industry—rightly, in my view—has made some public statements about what capacity there is to use plantation timber. Why wouldn't he? I would have been amazed if he had not, considering the fact that he owns one of the biggest softwood plantations in Australia. Good luck to him. In fact, I think it is the biggest plantation interest in Australia. Why wouldn't you take an opportunity to promote your own product? But the existing plantation resource is insufficient to supply all of our sawn timber requirements on a sustainable basis.
The whole debate about timber has been diverted to the issue of woodchips because that is a very easy image to put on television.

TALK.START.PARA: —A bit like Kakadu a few years back.

—Senator Alston, I would agree with you. The real debate, however, is about sawn timber, not about woodchips. That resource is insufficient. The Resource Assessment Commission did examine the effect—this is the bottom line, I know—of the immediate cessation of logging in native forests and predicted a shortfall of—
—What was the answer?

—If you're quiet, I'll tell you. It predicted a shortfall of 1.5 million cubic metres in hardwood sawn timber and a decline in employment of around 36,000 jobs. That is the analysis of the effect of immediately ceasing to produce it at all. A Commonwealth priority under the national forest policy statement is expansion of the plantation base. We will continue to do this through programs such as the farm forestry program and the North Queensland community rainforest reafforestation program, which is administered by my colleague—
—Are you listening, John?

—He administers it; he knows about it. This and a comprehensive and beneficial taxation ruling to clarify the taxation treatment of private forestry have all been initiatives taken. Through training and extension activities, landowners are learning how to establish and manage forestry plantations as a future resource for the industry. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. In relation to the maintenance of RAAF aircraft, I ask: why has the task of servicing the high-tech engines of Australia's FA18 fighters recently been taken away from Hawker de Havilland and contracted not to another Australian company but to Air New Zealand? Is it a fact that Air New Zealand has no significant engineering facilities in Australia and that the airline has no experience in handling such advanced engines? Is it a fact that this decision will cost the jobs of 57 workers at the Hawker de Havilland plant in Melbourne, where the engines were built and where they have been serviced since 1983? Was this decision based on the relatively favourable currency exchange rate with no consideration being given to factors such as quality, experience or Australian jobs?

—For the purposes of contracting work out, New Zealand and Australia are taken as one industry. That is as a result of the Anzac ship treaty, closer economic relations and closer defence relations. On many occasions Australian firms have benefited from that by winning contracts in New Zealand and doing the work in Australia.

PARA.TAB: The RAAF had to be absolutely certain in letting this contract that all companies that put in had the technical expertise to do so. It spent a lot of time establishing and checking that each of the bidders—there were more than two, as you probably know—had that expertise. Having established that fact, the question then came down to who would win the tender. The New Zealand firm won the tender, and won it overwhelmingly, and therefore was awarded the work.

The just recently published white paper made the point that New Zealand and Australia as a market in defence areas would be considered as one. I did not hear anyone from the opposition objecting at that particular point to its being one market because the benefits go both ways. In this case, the New Zealand firm won fair and square and by a very substantial margin. On other occasions Australian firms will win work for New Zealand defence products and will employ people in Australia.

So, whilst I regard it as a matter of regret that an Australian firm in this case was not competitive—it was competitive in the contract for helicopter engines that was awarded at about the same time—it was not a question of favouring any other firm. It was simply a question of letting the tender processes go. Each company entered that tender process knowing that the lowest price, if all other things were equal, would apply, and so it occurred.

TALK.START.PARA: —I fail to see how a company which has no experience in maintaining engines and no facilities for doing so can actually win over a company which has had experience since the engines were built, and indeed built the engines. Further to the question of maintenance of RAAF aircraft and other defence force aircraft, is it a fact that 24 of the army's fleet of 38 Blackhawk helicopters are currently grounded because of cracks, corrosion and shortage of spare parts? Were only three of the 27 helicopters based in Townsville serviceable last week? Did they cost half a billion dollars when they entered service in 1987?

—That supplementary question is an abuse of question time because it has absolutely no relevance to the first question asked. It is a substantive question which I would be prepared and happy to answer. On that particular point, I have to say that Senator Woods is right to be critical, as I am critical, of the performance of the army on the availability of Blackhawk helicopters. But it is impossible, right across the whole spectrum of defence equipment, not to have problems at some stage. Those problems are now being addressed. It was found that the Blackhawk, operating in Australian conditions, have a much higher requirement for spare parts than Sikorsky ever contemplated. We are now in the process of getting into the spare parts pipeline and putting more money in to make sure we have adequate spares. It is a criticism. It is not one related to the first part of your question. I accept the criticism of the performance in this area. It is an area we need to improve in.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner), to a question without notice asked by Senator Margetts this day, relating to greenhouse gases.

SPEECH.PARA: In response to a question from Senator Margetts, Senator Faulkner indicated that the government was committed to trying to reduce greenhouse emissions. As usual, the response is in the form of a levy or a tax. We went through this with superannuation. The first reform to superannuation meant getting an extra billion dollars out of people's superannuation savings. The second consideration was the prudential controls. The government is using the same tack in relation to greenhouse emissions. It wants to tax first, get extra revenue for the government and then look at scientific measures to reduce greenhouse emissions.

PARA.TAB: The point I also want to make today is that this is akin to a GST, but it has worse features than a GST because it falls very heavily on the productive costs of Australian industries. In addition, not only does it feed on to those costs; but also it feeds on to the costs of ordinary consumers. The sorts of people who are going to be hardest hit are those on fixed incomes and pensioners. For example, if you tax coal—coal is an essential ingredient in firing the furnaces for the generation of electricity—then those electricity costs will feed into ordinary consumers. Where is the offset to the industry which applies in the case of a GST? It is certainly of no benefit to consumers. People on fixed incomes, particularly pensioners, will be adversely affected by a carbon tax.

I will give one example to illustrate the very extensive damage that a carbon tax will do to Australian industry. In recent years the cement industry has undergone tremendous restructuring. We have now four or five very large and viable producers of cement in Australia. However Australian production is always under threat from imports. You may recall that during that restructuring there was talk of clinker coming in and competing adversely with Australian production.

I say to the environment minister, who is not here, that the problem with a carbon tax is that it will add significantly to the cost of producing cement here in Australia. It will add to the costs of the Australian cement producers, but at the same time the costs of the overseas suppliers will not be increased one iota. We have an additional imposition on Australian manufacturing which is taking jobs away from Australian people, reducing the efficiency of Australian manufacturing and making it competitively advantageous to bring that cement in from overseas. What sort of government do we have here?

We have just heard an eloquent response from Senator Murphy about protecting the jobs of Australian workers. He had the temerity to suggest that the opposition has no idea about protecting jobs of blue collar workers or protecting Australian industry. I put it to Senator Murphy and the government that this carbon tax will have a detrimental effect on jobs. We are warning you: the main issue at present appears to be how high that carbon tax should be, but the argument should be about putting into effect appropriate controls to ensure minimum emission. That is what the emphasis should be on—not raising revenue.

The issue seems to be about raising additional taxes and using protecting the environment as an excuse for doing that. But I say that you should turn around your priorities. Don't do what you did in superannuation—raise the $1 billion or so first and then look at the prudential controls. Look at the real environmental issues that will make some contribution to reducing greenhouse emissions. Don't just add taxes for the sake of it. TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Watson for discussing this matter further. I feel that a few points that he made cannot go unchallenged. Firstly, the major question that we have to consider in relation to using economic instruments in any way is: if the real cost of much of the environmental damage that takes place as a result of economic activity is not included by way of taxes or levies, who does pay? How equitable is that? Is it the workers who pay? What about the people who are going to suffer from the negative impacts of climate change?

PARA.TAB: You have only to look at the news reports coming from Europe right now—they refer to the breaking of dikes in the Netherlands and the rising waters in Europe—to see what the possible impacts could be if we continue to close our eyes and pretend that it is not happening to us, that it has nothing to do with us and that perhaps it is happening on another planet, in another place or in another universe altogether. Unfortunately, it is not. It is happening here.

We have had frequent debate about the impacts of drought. We know that we can expect more of these occurrences due to climate change as time goes by. It is not, as the National Farmers Federation suggests, something that will happen in a nice regulated way that will mean that some areas will get more rain and some areas will get less. We know the evidence is that it is associated with damaging weather patterns and disrupted weather patterns. There are economic and social costs as well as environmental costs. I want to know who the heck the opposition thinks is going to pay and when that payment should take place. We are talking perhaps about billions of dollars worth of damage that may take place even in our primary sector.

What kind of damage to human lives are we seeing take place now in Europe? Who should pay? Should the future pay? Should the kids pay? Should the environment pay? Should the species pay? When there are slightly increased temperatures in water currents, various species do not turn up at all. This is already happening. We should be able to model the effects of increasing numbers of El Nino events and when these will be likely to happen as a result of climate change. In such cases, entire fish species do not turn up or breed, entire bird species do not breed for three years in a row and animal species that are part of this change do not survive or, when they do—and others do not—they take over to create an imbalance in the system. Who pays for that? Who does the opposition suggest should pay for that? Often the farmers end up paying.

I was really interested when Senator Watson suggested that what he thought appropriate—I wrote this down—is putting in appropriate controls. I agree that not one thing will do it. We talked frequently about no-regrets policies. I have talked about them on a number of occasions because not even a no-regrets policy is being implemented in Australia. They would mean that we would have no regrets and the ability to both benefit the economy and improve greenhouse performance. We have not been doing even that.

I remember clearly one day giving details of how this might be implemented. Members of the opposition were standing up and asking, `Yes, but who will pay the bill?'. I said, `I don't believe this.' One can present information that is clearly available through studies that have been done. It is convenient to close one's ears and believe that it is not happening. So there is a no-regrets policy that is appropriate.

There is also the possibility that the real cost of economic decisions should be shared around, because in the end the future, the kids and the environment will end up paying. I agree that putting in appropriate controls is also important. But I cannot remember one time recently when the opposition has even agreed to having appropriate controls put on industry to make sure that it improves its environmental performance. TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make some of the same points made by Senator Margetts a moment ago in relation to the lack of concern which the opposition seems to show for the longer term costs. PARA.TAB: I will pick up what Senator Watson had to say. I agree with him that putting a tax on carbon based fuels and putting that money into general revenue is not the way to go. You do not tax the labour component, nor do you tax the value added component of good and services. I am surprised that Senator Watson is so wrong in that respect. Part of the way of doing that, they identify, is by taking that tax on carbon base fuels and channelling it back into things like house insulation, better house design, solar hot water services, better transport and more public transport—a whole range of things—all of which would stimulate Australian industry, all of which would provide employment and none of which would have any of the adverse consequences to which Senator Watson referred to a moment ago.

The present state and federal governments have a plan to build a national electricity grid. If you make that simple change you will see an enormous improvement in the efficiency with which electricity is used. You will see a reduction in the amount of electricity used and, despite an increase in the unit cost, you would see a reduction in the overall absolute costs of energy.

SPEECH.PARA: PAUL LENNON
SHADOW FORESTS MINISTER
27 JANUARY 1995

The Opposition will continue to seek guarantees from the Federal Government that over $200 million of planned downstream processing forest investments as well as jobs and all existing resource supplies to industry in Tasmania are protected.
The investments include:

PARA.TAB: The medium density fibre plant at George Town.
The Bridgewater veneer mill.
Gunn's woodchip licence.

SPEECH.PARA: Shadow Forests Minister Paul Lennon said Labor would continue to pressure the Federal Government to set in place a process that puts an end to the chaos that has been apparent of late.
Mr Lennon said the Opposition had been successful in convincing the Federal Government to reduce the number of coupes in Tasmania that will be subjected to further unnecessary assessment.
He said that only about 70 of the original 120-odd coupes in Tasmania would be now assessed.
This would minimise the impact that would otherwise have occurred in Tasmania.
This result had a lot to do with strong representation to the Prime Minister's office and Labor in Tasmania going to Canberra.

However, until a detailed assessment has been made of the areas the Commonwealth wants set aside, the Opposition did not know whether or not the 300,000 cubic metres of sawlog and veneer which supplies Tasmania's sawmilling industry were fully secure.

If prudent and feasible alternatives to the areas identified by the Commonwealth cannot be found then the Opposition will be requiring the Federal Government to again amend the coupe list for Tasmania.
Mr Lennon said the fact remained that the Commonwealth's response was largely political and highlighted the failure to put in place a proper process for forest management and protection.
"The process to make decisions on export woodchip licenses and other forestry matters until now has been appalling." he said.
"There has been no political leadership.
"Now that the PM has stepped in we can only hope that there will be a significant change and the Federal Government will be more responsive to both sides of the debate.

"We have been talking to the PM's office regularly and put our submission very strongly. We will continue to press the PM and the Federal Government to ensure investment and jobs are protected in Tasmania."
Mr Lennon said there remained a fear that the small sawmill industry could be at risk from today's decision and that this could lead to moves to log in the deferred forests.
"We don't want to see this happen," he said. "The deferred zones must be protected pending proper scientific assessment.
"We support the regional assessment process to better understand the value of our forests and for further protection and sustainability.
"It is now up to the Prime Minister and Premier Groom to make sure this happens.
"But there remains confusion over Mr Keating's statement in that it appears to appease the big woodchip companies while the small sawmillers will suffer.
"The Federal Government must do all it can to support the sawmilling industry."

Mr Lennon said more and more people were becoming sick and tired of the on-going forests debate and wanted to see a balanced agreement that took into account conservation issues, investment potential and jobs.

Dear Mal

Thank you for your letter of 31 January 1995 concerning Instrument No 45 of 1994, made under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986, a Statement of Principles concerning Gastro-Oesophageal Reflux Disease.

As I explained in my letter to you of 10 January 1995, Instrument No 45 of 1994 seeks to correct an error in Instrument No 24 of 1994. This instrument mistakenly included the phrase "death from gastro-oesophageal reflux disease of the pancreas." This occurred as a result of an administrative error.

Professor Donald of the Repatriation Medical Authority gave an assurance that deletion of the phrase "of the pancreas" would not disadvantage someone retrospectively, purely because it is medically impossible for someone to suffer from, or die as a result of, gastro-oesophageal reflux of the pancreas. Gastro-oesophageal reflux disease does not originate in, or affect, the pancreas.

The effect of including the words "of the pancreas" is to require that death be caused by gastro-oesophageal disease of the pancreas which, as I have pointed out, is a medical impossibility. This would retrospectively disadvantage any widow or widower claiming that a veteran's death was due to gastro-oesophageal reflux disease.

TALK.START.PARA: —I gave notice last Thursday that, on behalf of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, I would withdraw notices of motion of disallowance today in respect of two instruments of delegated legislation, namely, Instrument No. 45 of 1994 made under subsection 196B(3) of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 and an exemption under Regulation 207 of the Civil Aviation Regulations.

PARA.TAB: Both of these instruments were subject to a motion of disallowance of which I gave notice on 15 November 1994. The committee terms such notices as `protective'. They are protective in the sense that the notice allows time for the committee and the issuing authority to resolve matters about which the committee has concern regarding a particular instrument or group of instruments. Once the protective notice is given, 15 sitting days of the Senate can elapse before an instrument is deemed to have been disallowed due to the passage of time.

It is not unusual for the committee to give notice of disallowance where it is not satisfied with some aspect of an instrument and it is clear that the matter cannot be resolved within 15 sitting days of the tabling of that instrument. After that period of 15 sitting days has elapsed and no disallowance has taken place, it is not possible to take any action in relation to a delegated instrument. A protective notice of disallowance therefore must be given within the initial 15 sitting day period.

The committee has usually corresponded with the relevant minister before placing an instrument under a protective notice of disallowance. Informal discussions often take place after the initial correspondence is forwarded to the minister. Those discussions, when necessary, can lead to a resolution of matters of concern to the committee. The committee believes that this is the most appropriate way for it to discharge its responsibility to the Senate. It is preferable for the committee to resolve problems with delegated legislation, if that is possible, rather than concern the Senate with actual motions of disallowance.

Because the committee operates in the way which I have outlined, it has not considered it necessary to recommend disallowance of a delegated instrument to the Senate since 1988. On the other hand, the committee will not hesitate to recommend disallowance to the Senate if it deems that course of action to be necessary.

For the committee to operate as it does, it requires the cooperation of the agencies responsible for delegated legislation. The committee should not be placed in the position of giving notice of intention to withdraw a notice of disallowance, pending the receipt of a satisfactory response before the next sitting day. This is what occurred in relation to the two instruments to which I have already referred, namely, Instrument No. 45 of 1994 made under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 and an exemption under Regulation 207 of the Civil Aviation Regulations.

Last Thursday morning, the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances had not received satisfactory responses in relation to either of these instruments. The last day for resolving the motions of disallowance, however, was today. It was for this reason, on behalf of the committee, that I gave notice of my intention to withdraw each notice of disallowance. I made it clear on Thursday, however, that if satisfactory replies had not been received by today, I would not proceed with the withdrawal. The instruments would thus be deemed to be disallowed.

In the case of the former instrument, a response had been received by the committee, but the committee required further clarification. That information was not available by Thursday morning last. If the agency concerned had been more prompt in its initial response, the situation may not have been reached where the delegated legislation risked the possibility of lapsing because of effluxion of time. In this regard, my original correspondence to the minister was forwarded on 10 November 1994, but the minister's initial reply to that correspondence was dated some two months later on 10 January 1995.

In relation to the latter instrument, on behalf of the committee, I wrote to the minister on 18 October last outlining the committee's concerns. Not until Thursday of last week did the committee receive any written response, despite reminders from staff of the regulations and ordinances committee and finally by me direct to the minister's office. The blame does not lie directly with the minister, but the committee would expect he would inform his officers that correspondence from the committee should be answered promptly. For officers to do otherwise is treating the committee and the Senate with disdain.

Both responses were received by Thursday afternoon and I withdrew the protective notices some few minutes earlier today. It appears that the latter instrument is invalid, but as the time for its operation has now expired, nothing would have been gained by proceeding to disallowance. It may be necessary, however, for the committee to allude to this instrument further in its annual report.

I remind agencies that although the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances is a multi-party committee, politics do not intrude in its examination of delegated legislation. Its examination is confined to the principles as outlined in the Senate's standing order 23(3). That part of Standing Orders reads as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee shall scrutinise each instrument to ensure:
(a)that it is in accordance with the statute;
(b)that is does not trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties;

(c)that it does not unduly make the rights and liberties of citizens dependent upon administrative decisions which are not subject to review of their merits by a judicial or other independent tribunal; and
(d)that it does not contain matter more appropriate for parliamentary enactment.

Finally, I take this opportunity to thank those ministers and agencies that regularly cooperate fully with the committee. The matters which I have raised in relation to the circumstances surrounding the two particular instruments are certainly of concern but are, fortunately, exceptions to the norm.
