DEBATE.TITLE: PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION TO ASEAN INTER-PARLIAMENTARY ORGANISATION CONFERENCE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I present the report of the Australian parliamentary delegation to the 15th ASEAN Inter-Parliamentary Organisation Conference and bilateral visits to the Republic of Singapore and the Republic of Indonesia which took place between 12 September and 1 October 1994. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a pleasure for me to recall this excellent delegation that went from the Parliament of Australia to the ASEAN Inter-Parliamentary Organisation. It was also our privilege to represent the parliament in a bilateral visit to Singapore and another to Indonesia. During the course of the AIPO conference, the 15th AIPO conference, in Manila we took the spare time we had to make a number of strategic visits within the Philippines. This report, which is tabled both in the House of Representatives and here today, summarises the delegation's meetings in those three neighbouring countries of Australia and our participation as an observer group in the organisation of the ASEAN parliaments which meets each year in one of the five capitals in South East Asia. It has been my honour to represent the parliament at four of these AIPO conferences: way back in 1979 in Bangkok, the next year in Jakarta, about five years ago in Manila, and again this last year in Manila.

PARA.TAB: We have appropriate reflections upon the nature of such a delegation and the value to Australia in having more involvement with the parliaments of these five neighbouring countries. As a long serving senator with an interest in our neighbouring countries, I support the delegation's report in every particular, not least in urging our Presiding Officers and, indeed, all of us as colleagues together in the Senate and House of Representatives, to continue to go as an observer group to AIPO and to take the chance of such a visit to also conduct bilateral visits to two of the South-East Asian nations at the same time.

I wish to refer to our 21 recommendations, which are conveniently set out at the very beginning of the report. I should also add—maybe I am a little self-serving as one of those who helped put together this report—that in my view not only was this an excellent visit by three members of the House of Representatives, our admirable secretary, Mr Cleaver Elliott, who is in the chamber and did a first class job, and me but also this report is precise, it is focused as to action and it is imminently readable, of course, pending some critical material at the end of the report of interest to anyone who is picking up the whole report. There is an admirable set of photographs that pick up the flavour of what was a very happy and professional delegation from this parliament to the conference and these three nations.

Turning to the recommendations, I note with regard to our visit to Singapore that we have never had more open, constructive and closer relations between Australia and Singapore. At the time of our visit to Singapore the Prime Minister, Mr Goh, was visiting this country and was brilliantly received here, as we were in Singapore by not only the parliament, led by the speaker, who was technically our host, but also numerous ministers and officials in the areas where we sought to learn from the Singapore experience. We had talks with the minister for defence, for example, and his officials and note new initiatives that are being taken for the training of the Singapore defence force in various ways in Australia and involvement of our two nations together in a number of joint exercises.

I believe strongly, and did for many years leading up to this particular visit, that Australia and Singapore are well placed to be close allies in this region—stable, sensible, professional, I think highly competent in technical particulars—and this strong relationship is of a kind that will further generate similar relationships with Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Thailand and Brunei, all six of the ASEAN countries.

It is a statement that is so often made that Australia has a special relationship with these six ASEAN countries, and we would underline that. It is obviously important not only in foreign policy, defence and security terms but also in trade and, frankly, in cultural and people exchanges that we will have increasing involvement with each other in this important part of the Asia Pacific.

I note that our second recommendation refers to the airport in Singapore and to Singapore's greatly extended harbour, both of which are almost unrivalled in the world for efficiency and which serve our region to great advantage. I know that Hong Kong has a very busy airport—there are one or two airports in North America and Europe that rival the volume of traffic through an airport—but the Changi airport in Singapore is a model to the entire world for the way in which to conduct air traffic systems. There is a plan for a third runway, which I do not think will have the unfortunate political fallout that the present Labor government is copping from the third runway in Sydney. I draw senators' attention to the references that we have made to the talks we had about the airport and the harbour.

I note that we were greatly moved intellectually, especially emotionally, as we went to Changi to see the memorial of those Australians and others who were most unfortunately imprisoned at that place during the Second World War. In particular, we saw the museum erected there which, in all the detail of many photographs and exhibits, enables any visitor to capture a full impression of the horror of being a prisoner of war in Changi in the 1940s—50 years ago.

We also saw there a replica of the chapel that was erected by Australians in the Changi prisoner of war camp and was the place of worship for so many Christians and others during that difficult time. The actual original of the chapel is here in Canberra, and in our report we have called that at the 50th anniversary of these events consideration be given to how Australia could add resources for the further enhancement of the objectives of that museum and the memorial.

I note that Singapore has, in my estimation, become one of the most prosperous and technologically advanced cities in any part of the world. The Singapore people have added now an increasing sense of humour and an increasing relaxedness to be concerned about not only economic prosperity and technical achievement but also quality of life issues, and they are much more ready to understand neighbours such as Australia. I believe Australia and Singapore have a natural alliance to work together on all fronts in the years ahead.

With regard to the AIPO conference, there is a recommendation that relates to the East Asia growth area that the ASEAN nations have declared that includes the southern Philippines and the northern part of Indonesia and Brunei. This triangle, or economic growth area, attracts investment and other resources so that there is a three-country sharing of an area of development to the advantage of each nation. It is our observation that Australia ought to be a fourth part of that triangle, especially from the Northern Territory and South Australia, directly taking up opportunities for investment and trade in not only the field of cattle, live cattle and abattoirs, in, say, Davao city and Mindanao generally in the Philippines but also other opportunities that exist for us there.

The Northern Territory minister responsible for liaison with these neighbouring countries—he visited the parliament last week—is to be commended for the high credibility that he and the Northern Territory government have gained in these areas. We want to see all of Australia, not just the Northern Territory, taking up opportunities, not least in this growth area.

More generally, in recommendations 13 and 15 we again refer to Mindanao. With some degree of regret I note that, whilst I have visited the Philippines on a number of occasions, I have not yet visited Mindanao. I do not believe many members of parliament have. It is the largest island closest to Australia. It ought to be included in any future bilateral visit by this parliament to the Philippines. This area is receiving thousands of head of Australian cattle. It is also able to receive a wide range of imports that will, to advantage, be developed in the largely grasslands area and tropical climate of Mindanao. A matter of political structure is being resolved between representatives of some minorities in Mindanao, especially the Islamic peoples and the government in Manila. But, as this is all the more resolved in the coming months and years, I believe there will be a stable part of the southern Philippines that should gain greater Australian attention.

We draw attention to including a visit to Mindanao in any future visit. In recommendation 15 we also encourage a trade fair of Australia's exports relevant to all the Philippines and for that to visit Mindanao. In particular, there is a need for abattoir techniques to be extended with advantage because of the quality of meat that would then come from the abattoirs after the import of Australian cattle.

One member of parliament put to me, and I note this just anecdotally, that we give a large amount of aid each year to the Philippines. Australia gives about $50 million worth of development assistance to the Philippines. This particular member of parliament, a very influential man, said we just assume that it is all doing good things but on many fronts. He put to us the rather too extreme view, I believe, that all of this could be closed down and that we should put all of that $50 million into improving the cattle industry of the Philippines. He said Australia would make a huge mark that the whole nation would understand immediately as the great gift of Australia to the upgrading of the cattle industry in the Philippines. I do not endorse the simplicity of that replacement approach, but I mention it because I think greater publicity needs to be given in the Philippines to Australia's development assistance projects. Certainly, greater effort should be made in the area of cattle and abattoirs.

I refer briefly to the AIPO conference itself. Recommendations 6, 7 and 8 refer to that. I note that AIPO is the institution in our neighbouring countries which exists to promote democracy. Accordingly, it ought to continue to have the full attention of Australia as we wish to see democracy flourishing in countries which, from time to time, have had dictatorial periods and have had coups—have had quite undemocratic periods. The conference was marvellously conducted. It was worth the observation of each speech and debated resolution that was open to observer delegations such as Australia.

Whilst we were in the Philippines, we went to Subic Bay to see the new investment area. Incentives are given by the Philippines government for business that would then export from Subic's magnificent harbour to the region. That certainly should be understood by Australians interested in investing in this part of the world.

We also visited the site of the lahar volcanic flow, which we read about in our headlines when Mount Pinatubo erupted some months ago. The word `lahar' is an Indonesian word similar to our word `lava'. It is a kind of volcanic eruption where a mineral sand, once saturated with water, becomes a flowing mud. The problem after the eruption of the mountain was that, with continuing rain, the millions of tonnes of this mineral sand on the sides of the mountain in all directions flow further down into the valleys, literally engulfing villages, agricultural land, roadways and all of the infrastructure of the region.

Australia has, through AIDAB, given equipment to monitor the extent of the flow and to determine an analysis about where to best put dykes to limit the damage from the lahar flow. That equipment is working—we saw it—but further attention needs to be given by Australia's representatives and the Australian government to cooperating with the Philippines government to put some of that analysis into practice. There is, if you like, a ready plan but a failure to demonstrate action that will maximise the advantages for the local people. If we are serious about the value of the analysis that we have been able to provide and which is greatly appreciated—in fact, it is seen as the best mapping techniques that are available anywhere in the Philippines—we should enable more to be achieved in the practical engineering in recommendations flowing from the analysis.

In the Philippines the delegation met with the Commission on Elections, which still carries the full democratic objectives of the Corazon Aquino period. We also met with the Commission on Human Rights, about which I could say the same. We were inspired by the commissioners of these two important institutions and the continuing work for good electoral practice and for human rights which is so much supported in this parliament, indeed by the nation of Australia. In recommendations 11 and 12 of the report we have urged that there be open consultation between the Australian equivalent of these two important institutions.

I refer briefly to the Peace Panel, whereby the Philippines has taken a quite positive step to have discussions with three dissident groups. Parts of these dissident groups are armed and are armed insurrectionists against the government of the Philippines. One is the New Peoples Army—the old communist guerrilla group; the second, the Moro Islamic Liberation Front in the south; and the third, a right wing officers' group within the army. The discussions involve trying to win over these three groups to take part in the normal peaceful political process of the Philippines. We were greatly impressed by the clear objectives of that commission that has the backing of President Ramos. We certainly wish the heightened democracy that is to flow from this initiative every success.

We met with President Ramos and other ministers during our visit, and our references to that are in the report. In Indonesia we had three major stops at Jakarta, Surabaya and Dili in East Timor. I strongly recommend that any continuing delegations visiting Indonesia also visit the capital, a regional commercial area, and then an eastern islands area—in much the same way that was so successfully part of this delegation's experience.

Surabaya has a strong sister state relationship with Perth in Western Australia, and the Western Australian government now has a full-time commissioner in Surabaya. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating), a former minister for industry, John Button, and this delegation have visited Surabaya. It is a major concentration of some 30 million people with some quite high technology investments and some hopeful projects, such as in shipbuilding and aviation, which the minister for technology, Minister Habibi, has initiated.

We must in Australia have such a careful knowledge of our neighbours and of the opportunities for Australia that we do not go only to capital or traditional cities, like Jogjakarta, but that we go to major economic centres such as Surabaya. We need to see from this example of the Western Australia link with Surabaya what additional steps can be taken for similar relationships to the advantage of Australia and Indonesia. I certainly support recommendation 16, which says:

SPEECH.PARA: The delegation recommends the Commonwealth Government continue to reinforce Surabaya-Perth (WA) links and that Australian government and business representatives continue to develop their activities in the Surabaya region.

I come to what is in many ways the area of our visit that has gained the most attention—our time in East Timor. We were the first Australian parliamentarians to visit East Timor since the terrible events of the Dili massacre. Therefore, all seven pages of our report that relate to East Timor—as they are published today for the first time—should be read most carefully by all senators and members and, indeed, by members of the Australian public who are interested in what we did there and in what we have recommended.

PARA.TAB: We were able to meet with President Soeharto in Jakarta and we had one hour of discussion, not least about East Timor, human rights and a stable and prosperous outcome for the people of East Timor. It is the Australian government's policy and was the preceding Liberal-National Party policy, which is in no way challenged by us in the delegation or, indeed, as I hear it, by any emerging group within Australia, that we see East Timor as part of Indonesia. We are not putting that question into our minds at all. I know that Portugal has that view in the current hearing in the international court at the moment, but it is an established policy of almost 20 years now that East Timor is seen by the Australia government and the majority of Australian parliamentarians as a part of Indonesia.

Let it be equally understood that I do not know one member of the Australian parliament who has less than the highest regard for the rights of the people of East Timor to have a prosperous, stable and peaceful life and for their culture, their language and their religion to be secure. That is very much my view, and we found that steps need to be taken within Indonesia, directed by the central government of Indonesia, to further enhance those concerns being addressed and satisfied.

We met with Governor Soares; we also met with the speaker of the local parliament in Dili; we met with the commander of the army in Dili and other senior officers of the Indonesian army; and we also specifically met all of the Australian development assistance workers serving AIDAB in three main projects—an agricultural project, a water resources project and a veterinary project. A fourth project in technical education is in the pipeline. We have recommended not only endorsement of the AIDAB activities that are proceeding but that the third project, the veterinary project, be extended by having East Timorese people trained, with our assistance, in other parts of Indonesia where suitable veterinary training is available.

The core recommendation, and the most important politically in our whole report, is recommendation 19, which relates to a special status for East Timor within Indonesia. It is the view of the governor and of Bishop Belo, whom one of our delegation was able to meet—that is, the church—that the central government of Indonesia ought to give a green light to discussions to determine a special status within Indonesia for East Timor. The word `autonomy' comes to our mind. It was not a word that was directly used by the governor, but I believe that Governor Soares and Bishop Belo are right and are representative of the people in East Timor in seeking sufficient special status or—using my term—autonomy within Indonesia that guarantees culture, religion and participation in the public service and other areas of the community in East Timor.

Finally, we have called on the government of Indonesia to reduce the number of military and police personnel in East Timor to the more generally prevailing numbers in other areas of Indonesia. I commend all those who helped us in our delegation's visits.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT AND ACCOUNTABILITY BILL 1994

Mr President. The introduction of this bill, together with the two others that are part of the same package, are to replace the Audit Act 1901. That act is one of the few Commonwealth laws that has operated continuously since it was passed by this Parliament in its first Session after Federation. Its intended replacement, therefore, represents something of a landmark in the history of Commonwealth financial administration.

The Audit Act is not being replaced simply because it is old. In fact, it has proved remarkably robust over its 93-year life in providing for the procedural framework for Commonwealth financial administration and for the audit of the Commonwealth's activities. But too many of its basic concepts and structures reflect their Nineteenth Century origins to an extent that ignores and, in some cases, even impedes modern management practice and contemporary expectations for public sector accountability.

These limitations were recognised by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts in the course of its comprehensive inquiry into the operations of the Audit Office. In its Report 296, tabled in April 1989, the JCPA recommended that the Audit Act 1901 be replaced with more modern legislation, with separate acts to deal with auditing and financial administration.

In giving effect to that recommendation, the Government believes that clarity would be served best through the adoption of three new acts. It is proposed that there be an Auditor-General Act to provide for the powers and functions of the Auditor-General. In relation to financial administration, however, Commonwealth bodies differ according to the basic legal financial status that each one has—namely, whether the body has the legal capacity, in its own right, to acquire ownership of money and other assets coming into its possession, or whether it acts only as a financial and custodial agent for the Commonwealth, without acquiring separate legal ownership of such money and assets. Consequently, it is proposed that there be a Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Act to specify certain matters that are to apply to the operations of financially autonomous bodies—that is, Commonwealth bodies that have legal ownership of money in their own right; and a Financial Management and Accountability Act, to apply to the financial operations of agencies—that is, Commonwealth bodies that, financially, are agents of the Commonwealth in that the bodies acquire no legal ownership of the money that they raise and spend. That money, in the Constitutional sense, directly comprises the `Treasury of the Commonwealth'.

Mr President, you may be aware that, upon introduction of the package of these three bills into the House of Representatives, the House agreed that the legislative package be referred to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts for its consideration and advisory report.

JCPA Report 331 tabled on 22 September 1994 is the result of that process. I believe that the Committee is to be commended for its quality analysis and recommendations, the great majority of which the Government has accepted and which have now been incorporated into the respective bills.
Mr President, I now wish to provide an outline of the proposed Financial Management and Accountability Act.

The proposed act is concerned with the regulatory/accounting/accountability framework for dealing with and managing the money and property of the Commonwealth. It will specify responsibilities and powers necessary for the efficient, effective and ethical use of the resources lawfully available to the Commonwealth to carry out its programs; and it will provide appropriate mechanisms to ensure that the stewardship and management performance of those who are responsible for those resources can be made visible and, thereby, allow them to be held accountable. The proposed law will add substance to the spirit of the public sector financial reforms that have been a feature of this Government's administration over the last decade. At the same time, the proposed Financial Management and Accountability Act is intended to preserve the traditional strengths of the Audit Act's key principles of financial control and, where possible, to clarify and simplify them.
Mr President, the Explanatory Memorandum accompanying this bill deals comprehensively with its features. There are, however, a few elements that I would like to mention specifically.

The definitions of "Agency", "Chief Executive", "official", "public money" and "public property", between them, describe the proposed boundaries of the act's application. Within those boundaries, the principles set down in the act will be fleshed out, where necessary, by subsidiary legislation—regulations and Finance Minister's Orders—to provide procedural substance for the day-to-day application of those principles. Such a legislative framework is patterned on the structure established by the Audit Act 1901 for regulations and Finance Directions, except that, unlike Finance Directions which are administrative in character, provision is made for Finance Minister's Orders to be tabled as disallowable instruments. The legislative framework will be completed by instructions which Chief Executives will be authorised to issue to officials of their agencies.

The act will preserve the unique role of the Minister for Finance, which is central to the orderly functioning of the Commonwealth's financial administration. The Finance Minister is, for all practical purposes, the custodian of the Constitutional `Treasury of the Commonwealth' so that the range of statutory powers and responsibilities for the proper custody of the Commonwealth's money is vested in that Office. The Finance Minister will retain the sole power to agree appropriate banking arrangements for public money; to make Orders concerning the handling of receipts and withdrawals of public money; and to its investment. The existing power under the Audit Act 1901 to arrange overdrafts and advances from banks has been clarified to specifically limit such arrangements as short term cash management tools—overdrafts on operational bank accounts for up to 30 days; borrowings from banks as advances paid to the Commonwealth for up to 90 days; and other types of credit arrangements, to be prescribed by the regulations, such as those represented by credit card and Cabcharge transactions, for up to 60 days. It should be noted that these arrangements confer no power for the Commonwealth to spend otherwise than as authorised by Parliament through appropriations.

One of the most visible changes to be brought about by the proposed Financial Management and Accountability Act is in relation to the accounting classifications of money in the Commonwealth's possession. The Trust Fund established by section 60 of the Audit Act 1901 is to be abolished and replaced by two, purpose-based, Funds—the Reserved Money Fund and the Commercial Activities Fund. Apart from components of the Reserved Money Fund that may be established pursuant to other enactments, the components of these two Funds will be established or varied by Finance Minister's determinations. The effect of such determinations will be to specify the kinds of money that may be drawn from the Consolidated Revenue Fund or Loan Fund and credited to the particular component and the purposes on which that money may then be spent. Since the spending of money from such a Fund is, in all respects, an appropriation, the proposed act will require that these determinations by the Finance Minister be tabled as disallowable instruments that do not take effect until the period for disallowance has passed. This procedure is more visible and provides a greater measure of Parliamentary control than has traditionally been the case in the establishment of Trust Accounts under the Audit Act 1901.

Payments of public money, including debiting a Fund against an appropriation, will be controlled by a system of "Drawing Rights", to be issued by the Finance Minister. This system is predicated on the fact that the laws made by Parliament relating to appropriations, variously compelling or permitting the Executive Government to spend, always specify the Fund being appropriated and the purpose of the spending. Such laws may also specify an amount and a timeframe. It would be a breach of section 83 of the Constitution for spending to occur in any instance outside of those parameters, so the act will stipulate that the Finance Minister has no capacity to issue valid Drawing Rights that are inconsistent with the terms of the relevant appropriation law; and makes it an indictable offence for an official or Minister to knowingly spend, or seek to spend, otherwise than in accordance with a valid Drawing Right.

The act would create a standing appropriation out of which rewards could be paid in certain circumstances for information furnished that led to the apprehension of persons defrauding the Commonwealth. The Government acknowledges that there is a range of viewpoints as to whether it is appropriate to pay rewards—even in the limited circumstances envisaged by this provision in the bill. The decision to include it, however, was taken only after carefully considering the issues and it reflects the Government's strong commitment to deter and detect fraud against the Commonwealth.

The act would put into the principal legislation the powers that are presently carried only in Finance Regulations in relation to providing a source of authority for the Presiding Officers to approve expenditure under appropriations for Parliamentary Departments.

The present Audit Act 1901 is generally silent on matters of management performance. The new act seeks to remedy this through particular responsibilities being expressly placed on Chief Executives of Agencies for which they may then be held accountable. They are to be required to manage the affairs of their Agencies efficiently, effectively and ethically to the extent allowed by law. They will also be required to implement fraud control plans and establish Audit Committees. The accountability mechanisms to mesh with these responsibilities will include powers of the Finance Minister to obtain financial statements and other reports more frequently than annually from Agencies.

Importantly, it is proposed that Chief Executives be permitted to sub-delegate to officials any of the act's Finance Minister's powers or functions, unless the Minister has imposed a restriction prohibiting or limiting such sub-delegation. These arrangements for sub-delegating are intended to achieve a major strengthening in the financial framework. Chief Executives are better placed than the Finance Minister to manage, to monitor and to control the activities of those officials who perform the delegated tasks. It will thus be practicable to hold Chief Executives accountable to the Finance Minister in these respects, whereas it is currently quite impracticable to do so under the existing Audit Act's delegation structures where thousands of individual officials are directly delegated by the Finance Minister.
Mr President, the Government believes that this proposed law represents a significant landmark in sharpening and strengthening the framework of Commonwealth financial administration.
I present the explanatory memorandum to the bill and commend the bill to the Senate.
COMMONWEALTH AUTHORITIES AND COMPANIES BILL 1994
Mr President, the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Bill 1994 is one of three bills forming the package of legislation to replace the Audit Act 1901

These bills were introduced into the House of Representatives on 29 June 1994, by the Minister for Finance, the Honourable Kim C. Beazley, MP. After their first reading, the bills were referred to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts for review and for an advisory report. The Committee reported to the House on 22 September 1994 (JCPA Report No.331 refers).

The Government moved a number of amendments to this package of legislation to pick up issues that were considered following the report on the three bills by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. The Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Bill 1994 and these amendments were passed by the House of Representatives on 8 December 1994.

This bill seeks to replace and enhance Part XI of the Audit Act 1901, which currently provides standard financial provisions for Commonwealth authorities and certain other bodies. It is also intended in due course that the proposed Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Act will replace individual financial provisions contained in the enabling legislation of authorities not subject to Part XI.

Mr President, the underlying purpose of the proposed Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Act is to replace, with a single set of requirements, the myriad of variations on a similar theme scattered throughout the enabling legislation of Commonwealth authorities and the constitutions of Commonwealth companies. The approach proposed by this bill would enable the accountability requirements of Commonwealth controlled bodies to be viewed as a whole and should significantly streamline the focus of the Government's and the Parliament's interest in this area.

Broadly, the bill proposes a single set of core reporting and auditing requirements for directors of `Commonwealth authorities' and sets out standards of conduct for executive officers. Many of these requirements are modelled on comparable areas of the Corporations Law as well as best practice currently applying to individual authorities. The bill also proposes a single set of requirements for ensuring that `wholly-owned Commonwealth companies' keep Ministers and the Parliament informed of their activities.

In particular, Mr President, this bill seeks to extend the mandate of the Auditor-General to be the sole external auditor of all Commonwealth authorities and companies, and their subsidiaries, without exception. At the same time it would modernise the requirements for the Auditor-General's reports on authorities making them consistent with those required by the Corporations Law.

In some areas, the bill traverses ground that is covered, to varying degrees, in the enabling legislation of authorities and the constitutional documents of companies. These areas of overlap will be removed by consequential amendments to the enabling legislation and are contained in the Audit (Transitional and Miscellaneous) Amendment Bill 1995 to be introduced into the Senate these sittings. Similarly, it is intended to replace areas of overlap in the memoranda and articles of association of Commonwealth companies with cross-references to the proposed Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Act.

For the purposes of the bill, a `Commonwealth authority' is, in essence, one established by an act as a body corporate for a public purpose and which holds money on its own account. A `Commonwealth company' is one in which the Commonwealth has a direct controlling interest (that is, there is no interposed entity between the company and the Commonwealth).

All Commonwealth companies will be subject to the requirement for the Auditor-General to report on their financial statements, and the financial statements of their subsidiaries, and for their annual reports to be tabled in the Parliament. However, only `wholly-owned Commonwealth companies' are to be subject to the other provisions in the bill relating to companies. This reflects the difficulty—in the case of Commonwealth controlled companies which have private shareholders—of imposing a general regime which requires the provision of certain reports, documents and information only to Ministers, namely, a risk of oppression actions under the Corporations Law by minority shareholders who might perceive discrimination against their interests.
Mr President, I will now briefly outline the main provisions of the proposed Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Act.
The annual report is seen as the centrepiece of directors' accountability to the Parliament.

The bill proposes that directors of Commonwealth authorities must prepare an annual report containing a report of operations, financial statements and a report by the Auditor-General on the financial statements. The report of operations and the financial statements must be prepared in accordance with Finance Minister's Orders and the directors and the Auditor-General must certify whether, in their opinion, the financial statements give a `true and fair view' of the matters required to be report ed.

I should mention, Mr President, that the proposed obligations on directors, as individuals, will replace more general obligations on authorities under existing arrangements. This approach is similar in principle to that applied to companies by the Corporations Law and is intended to clarify the accountability arrangements.

I should also mention that the Finance Minister's Orders will be disallowable instruments, thereby ensuring an ongoing role for the Parliament in determining the reporting obligations of directors of Commonwealth authorities.

The directors of both Commonwealth authorities and Commonwealth companies will be required to give the responsible Minister a copy of their annual report, or annual general meeting documents, which the Minister must in turn table in each House of the Parliament. In the case of Commonwealth companies that are not wholly-owned the Minister must table their annual reports as soon as practicable after the annual general meeting. This requirement recognises that, where there are shareholders other than the Commonwealth, it is reasonable to allow all the shareholders in general meeting the opportunity to consider the annual report before it is tabled.
Mr President, there are a number of other reporting obligations proposed by this bill.

The Finance Minister may require Commonwealth authorities and wholly-owned companies to prepare half-yearly or quarterly financial statements. The statements must be given to the responsible Minister within 2 months after the end of the period to which they relate and must be tabled in each House as soon as practicable. It is envisaged that this requirement to prepare interim financial statements will mainly be applied to bodies with a high degree of independence, such as Government Business Enterprises (GBEs). Of course, as the Government, from time to time, develops new approaches to providing the services now provided by GBEs, there may be a need to look again at how the proposed act will apply to those bodies.

Directors will be required to keep the responsible Minister informed of the operations of Commonwealth authorities and wholly-owned companies, including their subsidiaries, and to give the responsible Minister and the Finance Minister such reports, documents and information as they may require.

Where the Finance Minister requires such reports, documents and information it is intended that, in the normal course, he or she will first consult with the responsible Minister and provide a copy of such reports or documents to that Minister. Such consultative arrangements have not been included in the bill because of long standing policy, reaffirmed by successive governments, that, as a general rule, the internal operations of government should not be reflected in legislation.

Directors must also notify the responsible Minister of certain proposed activities such as significant acquisitions or disposals of shares or businesses, changes in business activities or involvement in partnerships, trusts or joint ventures. However, the responsible Minister may give written guidelines as to the coverage of the matters to be notified and may in writing exempt the directors from notifying particulars of proposals to form or participate in the formation of a company.

Directors of a Government Business Enterprise, whether constituted as an authority or a company, must prepare a corporate plan at least once a year and give it to the responsible Minister. This is a key planning document that will provide the responsible Minister with financial and other performance information.
Mr President, the bill also contains a number of miscellaneous provisions relating to the governance of Commonwealth authorities and wholly-owned Commonwealth companies.

It proposes that the responsible Minister may, after consulting with directors, notify them of general policies of the Government that are capable of being applied to the authority or company concerned. The directors must ensure that such policies are carried out and, as far as practicable, ensure that they are also carried out in relation to any subsidiaries. Such policies cannot be in conflict with any statutory obligations of a particular authority or company. This provision is intended to cover government policies that are applicable to the Commonwealth public sector in general, such as, for example, policies relating to trade contact with foreign countries or equal employment opportunity. Nevertheless, in recognition of their special roles, and so as to avoid any misconceptions insofar as the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and the Special Broadcasting Service are concerned, the Audit (Transitional and Miscellaneous) Amendment Bill 1995 will make it abundantly clear that this provision cannot affect the content or scheduling of programs of those bodies.

The bill also provides that directors must establish and maintain an audit committee. The Government views this as a step in improving internal control and communication within Commonwealth authorities and wholly-owned companies as well as the accountability of their management. It will also ensure that directors have appropriate assistance in the discharge of their accounting and financial reporting obligations.

Consistent with the Government's response to a recommendation by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration in its 1989 report on Government Companies and their Reporting Requirements, the bill provides that a Commonwealth authority must ensure that none of its subsidiaries does anything that the authority itself does not have power to do. This does not, of course, preclude the Parliament from passing legislation to empower a subsidiary to perform a particular activity that exceeds the powers of its parent.

Mr President, the bill imposes standards of conduct on executive officers of Commonwealth authorities broadly equivalent to the standards already imposed on executive officers of companies by the Corporations Law. Executive officers include directors and any other persons who are concerned in, or take part in, the management of the authority.

Specifically, the bill provides that `executive officers' must at all times act honestly and exercise a reasonable degree of care and diligence in the exercise of their powers and the discharge of their duties. Also, an executive officer, or former executive officer, must not make improper use of inside information, or of his or her position as an executive officer, in order to gain an advantage for any person, either directly or indirectly, or cause detriment to the authority.
Both criminal and civil sanctions are provided for contravention of these provisions.

In addition, a director of a Commonwealth authority who has an interest in a matter that is being considered, or about to be considered, by the Board, must, as soon as possible after he or she becomes aware of the situation, disclose the nature of the interest concerned at a meeting of the Board. The director must not participate in deliberations on the matter concerned unless the Board or the responsible Minister determines otherwise.

Finally, Mr President, in accordance with the Government's response to another recommendation by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration in its report on Government Companies and their Reporting Requirements, the bill provides that the responsible Minister shall table in each House particulars of any new or varied direct Commonwealth interest in a company. The particulars required are to be prescribed by regulation.

Mr President, the proposals put forward in this bill will have no direct impact on Government revenues or outlays. However, I am confident that, through the implementation of a more streamlined and consistent operational and accountability framework for Commonwealth authorities and companies, improved performance and value for money will be achieved both for the Commonwealth and Australians generally.
Mr President, I present the explanatory memorandum to the bill and commend the bill to the Senate.
AUDITOR-GENERAL BILL 1994

Mr President. This bill is one of the package of three bills to replace the Audit Act 1901. The other two bills are the Financial Management and Accountability Bill 1994 and the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Bill 1994.

The purposes of the Auditor-General Bill 1994 are to continue the statutory Office of the Auditor-General for the Commonwealth of Australia; to specify the powers and functions of the Auditor-General; to establish the Australian National Audit Office; and to provide, in turn, for the independent audit of the Australian National Audit Office.

The bill draws heavily on the recommendations of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts (JCPA) in Report 296—"The Auditor-General: Ally of the People and Parliament". The effect of the bill's proposed provisions will be to support the continued functional and professional independence of the Auditor-General from the Executive Government. The corollary is that the Auditor-General's special relationship with the Parliament is protected.
Mr President, I now wish to provide an outline of the proposed Auditor-General Act.

The bill specifies there is to be an Auditor-General for the Commonwealth of Australia and details the appointment and conditions of the Office. The Auditor-General will continue to be appointed by the Governor-General on the recommendation of the appropriate Minister—which, under the Administrative Arrangements Orders, will be the Prime Minister. Under arrangements proposed in this bill, prior to advising the Governor-General, the Prime Minister must consult with the Finance Minister, a nominee of the Leader of the Opposition, the Chairman of the JCPA and the Chairperson of the Audit Committee of the Parliament, when established. The bill also includes provisions for the removal of the Auditor-General by the Governor-General following a petition by both Houses of the Parliament in the same session.

The Auditor-General has a broad mandate to be enshrined in legislation, replacing the existing arrangements whereby the Auditor-General's mandate is only partly derived from legislation and partly from Government policy. The Auditor-General will have a mandate to undertake the audit of the financial statements of all Commonwealth bodies. In addition, the Auditor-General may undertake performance audits of the operations of Commonwealth bodies at his or her discretion, the only exception being in respect of Government Business Enterprises (GBEs) where the accountability framework established by the Government requires GBEs to focus on performance and to improve the return to the Commonwealth as shareholder. Despite the focus on performance by GBEs, the Government nevertheless proposes that Parliament or a Minister may request the Auditor-General to carry out a performance audit of a GBE or GBE subsidiary, provided that, if the body concerned is a company, it is a company wholly-owned by the Commonwealth. In this regard, the Government has reflected on the need to continue the principle, as already accepted under the Audit Act 1901, of forbearance in consideration of the investment interests of private shareholders in partially privatised Commonwealth companies. Performance audits are an extra feature on the accountability landscape peculiar to public sector bodies. It does not follow, however, that the often high Parliamentary profile given the reports of such audits would always be beneficial to the interests of the companies' private investor/shareholders.

The bill seeks to permit the Auditor-General to enter into an arrangement with any person or body to conduct financial statements audits or performance audits, or to provide services that are of a kind that are normally performed by auditors. These arrangements would be at the discretion of the Auditor-General and be undertaken where he or she considers there is a benefit to the Commonwealth.

The bill proposes that the Auditor-General and authorised officials have full and free access to information, documents and premises. These powers are considerable in their scope, but are necessary if the Auditor-General is to fulfil his or her obligations to the Parliament. The information gathering powers are complemented with strong secrecy and penalty provisions for any person performing an Auditor-General function.

Mr President, the bill seeks to establish the Australian National Audit Office as a statutory authority with the sole function of assisting the Auditor-General. The staff of the Australian National Audit Office are to be appointed or employed under the Public Service Act 1922, as a reflection of its status as a core public service. Nevertheless, should the staff's existing skills and expertise need to be augmented from time to time, the bill also seeks to preserve the Auditor-General's flexibility to engage any person—for example, to contract with auditors or other specialists from the private sector—to assist in the performance of an Auditor-General function. The Government sees the establishment of the Australian National Audit Office as a statutory authority as an important symbolic step to demonstrate its commitment to the independence of the Auditor-General and his or her office.

Further, the bill would establish the office of Independent Auditor who is the Parliament's auditor of the Australian National Audit Office. It provides for the appointment and conditions of the Office which, as far as are appropriate, mirror those of the Auditor-General in relation to his or her audit functions for the balance of the Common wealth.

The Independent Auditor is to be a part-time statutory officer appointed by the Governor-General on the advice of the appropriate Minister who will have first consulted with the Chairman of the JCPA and the Chairperson of the Audit Committee of the Parliament, when established. The Independent Auditor is to hold qualifications and have the experience determined necessary by the Minister after consultation with the Chairman of the JCPA.

Mr President, as previously indicated, the Government has drawn heavily on the recommendations of the JCPA in framing this legislation. While the Committee's recommendations have not been taken up in their entirety, the provisions of this bill and the complementary provisions in the other two bills in the package ensure that the Auditor-General can fulfil, independently, the role demanded by this Parliament, and with all the professional and functional freedom required for the task.
The Auditor-General plays a vital role in giving credibility to Australia's system of Parliamentary governance and this legislation will preserve and strengthen that role.
Mr President, I present the explanatory memorandum to the bill and commend the bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill proposes amendments to the Excise Tariff Act 1921 to incorporate in that act three Excise Tariff Proposals that have been previously tabled in the Parliament.
Excise Tariff Proposal No. 2 of 1994

Clause 5 of the bill proposes a decrease in the excise duty payable on fuel oil, heating oil and kerosene of 1.977 cents per litre and a decrease in the excise duty payable on topped crude oil of 2.977 cents per litre. These changes were announced in the 1994-95 Budget and are effective from 11 May 1994. Clause 3 of the bill proposes to remove topped crude oil from the 1 cent per litre increase in excise duty of 1 August 1994.

The decrease in excise duty on these products is proposed to partly offset the 3 cents per litre increase in excise duty on these products that was announced in the 1993-94 Budget. The proposed decrease is in response to representations from industry that the increase in excise duty on fuel oil has had significant impact on input costs of certain export oriented mining and mineral processing operations and the coastal shipping industry. Topped crude oil was subject to a further 1 cent per litre increase in excise duty on 1 February 1994, independent of indexation, and a further increase of 1 cent per litre was scheduled for 1 August 1994. The decrease in excise duty on topped crude oil, which can be used as a substitute for fuel oil, will also re-align topped crude oil with the excise duty on fuel oil.
Excise Tariff Proposal No. 3 of 1994

Clause 6 of the bill proposes a decrease in the excise duty payable on aviation gasoline (avgas) and an increase in the excise duty payable on aviation kerosene (avtur). The decrease in the excise duty on avgas is a net reduction of 6.327 cents per litre and is the combination of a 1.194 cents per litre increase and a 7.521 cents per litre decrease in excise duty. The 1.194 cents per litre increase is a continuation of the phase in arrangements for cost recovery with respect to air safety regulation by the Civil Aviation Authority which commenced in the Excise Tariff Amendment Act 1994. The 7.521 cents per litre decrease is the result of revised costing arrangements by the Civil Aviation Authority for airways services provided for avgas powered aircraft. This decrease recognises that a large proportion of Civil Aviation Authority facilities are provided in respect of public transport operations mostly undertaken by avtur powered aircraft.

The 1.194 cents per litre increase in the excise duty on avtur is a continuation of the phase in arrangements for cost recovery with respect to air safety regulation by the Civil Aviation Authority commenced in the Excise Tariff Amendment Act 1994.
A long term funding strategy for aviation safety regulation is being developed by the Civil Aviation Authority in consultation with the aviation industry to apply from 1 July 1995.
Excise Tariff Proposal No. 4 of 1994

Clause 4 of the bill proposes to exempt certain uses of stabilised crude petroleum oil and condensate from excise duty. It proposes to impose excise duty on stabilised crude petroleum oil and condensate only for use as a fuel otherwise than where for use as a fuel in the recovery, production, transportation or refining of stabilised crude oil or condensate.
Financial Impact Statement

The increase of 1.194 cents per litre in the excise duty on avtur is balanced by an equivalent increase in the moneys appropriated to the Civil Aviation Authority. The financial impact is neutral.
(c) Excise Tariff Proposal No. 4 of 1994
The amendments proposed by Excise Tariff Proposal No. 4 have no financial impact.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Life Insurance Bill 1994 and the Life Insurance (Consequential Amendments and Repeals) Bill 1994. The Life Insurance (Consequential Amendments and Repeals) Bill repeals two previous acts concerned with levies—the Life Insurance Policy Holders' Protection Levies Act 1991 and the Life Insurance Policy Holders' Protection Levies Collection Act 1991. Honourable senators may recall that one of these acts deals with the dreadful saga associated with the Occidental and Regal Life fiasco. We are reminded that the levies will no longer be required. Therefore, it is not surprising that this act has been repealed.

PARA.TAB: However, I use this opportunity of reminding honourable senators that not all policy holders are happy. There are still some outstanding issues in relation to this Occidental-Regal fiasco. There are still a lot of questions asked and people believe that they still have not received their correct entitlement. I ask the government to attend to these issues I have raised.

The bill also seeks to amend something like 17 further acts of parliament that have references to life insurance matters within them. The bill also updates annual report requirements of the commissioner and puts pressure on the Treasurer in terms of disclosure and disclosing responsibilities to the parliament in a timely fashion. The bill gives added protection to the savings of policy holders and adds additional supervisory costs in the process. The supervisory levy will rise to about $70,000 per company, more than 2 1/2 times the previous fee. There is also the establishment of actuarial standards. It is intended to develop actuarial standards with the object of tightening prudential controls and instituting uniform rules. Solvency and capital adequacy measures will also be tightened, which is overdue.

I remind the Senate that, since the bill was first introduced, there have been two further sets of amendments—the latest arriving this morning. Industry representatives, through LIFA, assure me that that organisation has had very close consultation and that all the amendments give effect to the previous concerns of the industry, although at times the language may not be what the industry required.

These two bills that the Senate is debating are not the end of the story so far as life insurance is concerned. It is a pity that it could not have been presented as a package and as an integrated whole. As I mentioned, since they were first introduced we have had two sets of supplementary amendments. They are two issues still outstanding which will require legislation. One relates to consumer protection. Undoubtedly, this will cost life companies money and, at the same time, provide a greater measure of protection to consumer interests. Also to be finalised is a code of conduct in relation to the practices of life writers. I hardly need to remind honourable senators that life writer membership has been decimated in recent years, with traditional life insurance companies going through some massive restructuring. Before that bill in relation to the code of practice comes before the parliament, issues have to be satisfied as to whether the government agency should be responsible for regulating agents or life underwriters, or whether the life companies themselves should be responsible, or whether there should be self-regulation by the agents themselves. These issues are yet to be determined.

I do not wish to go through the main bill in great detail. However, I would like to refer to the contributions of members in the House of Representatives. I particularly draw attention to the contributions made by members on our side of politics—my colleagues David Connolly, Allan Rocher and Alan Cadman. Seeing that there is nothing contentious in these issues, which were largely of a mechanical nature, it is not the appropriate role of the Senate to repeat them, except to draw attention to certain concerns and new issues that we believe should arise.

I compliment the government and its representatives on the fact that, on this occasion, they have had very extensive consultations with the industry. When we were looking at a previous bill in relation to general insurance, it took some time before that consultation reached a desirable level. However, with that experience behind them, the Insurance and Superannuation Commission and the other representatives from government have consulted widely within the industry and appropriately have responded. The latest series of amendments, which were tabled for the first time today, reflect what can be done when we adopt such a cooperative approach.

I remind the Senate that this life bill is perhaps the third in a row flowing from very comprehensive changes which were made in the area of superannuation, general insurance and now life insurance. Perhaps a valid criticism from the industry is the concern about directors' responsibilities. Certainly, those responsibilities actually exceed those which were imposed upon trustees or directors under general corporate law. However, there has been some moderation in terms of due diligence concepts which have been introduced as a result of amendments. For example, amendment 5 clarifies the duty of a company to act reasonably, based on the circumstances at the time of its activities and its decisions, and considering the interests of policy holders, et cetera.

This concept of acting reasonably takes away what was previously there in terms of the absolute guidance which these sorts of provisions are intended to give to the courts when interpreting disputed issues. As a result of the latest series of 13 amendments, I think what the government and the ISC intend is a lot clearer to the courts.

In determining outcomes, courts look to the legislation for the sorts of guidelines the parliament expected in terms of interpretation. I think this is a very desirable message to send to courts. Taken away is the concept of benefit in hindsight because in hindsight we can always be very clever. What is important is that at the time the decisions were taken, the people who have responsibilities in this area, namely the directors, acted reasonably.

I do not intend to take additional time of the Senate, but instead refer my colleagues to the excellent contributions made in the House of Representatives which encapsulate the issues very satisfactorily. I hope the government continues to consult widely.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES

TALK.START.PARA: —The bills before us today establish a new regulatory framework for the life insurance industry. I say at the outset that the Democrats have no difficulty with this legislation and will be supporting it. The key provisions have been well rehearsed already, both here and in the other place. Essentially, the industry will have to meet new solvency and reporting requirements. The industry will also be subjected to a higher level of supervision by the Insurance and Superannuation Commission.

PARA.TAB: In the interests of fairness and constructive debate, I say here, as has already been said, that there has been considerable consultation. It does appear to have been one of the government's better efforts in actually getting out and listening to people and then taking what it has heard on board and making significant improvements in legislation. I should perhaps qualify that statement just a little by saying that we have had instances in the past where apparently solid pieces of complex legislation have failed in unexpected ways. But perhaps what I can say is that if there are any traps in this legislation they have been well hidden.

The one concern the Democrats have relates to what is not in this bill rather than what is in it. In August last year the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer, Mr Elliott, released a draft code of practice governing the sale of life insurance. His statement announced the government's intention to finalise the code in time for the passage of this legislation. The idea was to make it enforceable and disallowable by way of new consumer protection provisions to be incorporated in this bill.

It turns out that the code and the amendments have not been finalised and will now have to be dealt with under amending legislation at some later date. My information is that draft legislation has been circulated confidentially and that the code is being finalised through a couple of parallel processes. So it now is not clear just when the consumer protection measures will come before this chamber. What is clear is that they are likely to be more contentious than the prudential legislation we are debating today. I say again: it is most unfortunate that we are not able to debate all of these measures, all of the reforms, in their entirety.

I will spend a little time outlining our concerns with the draft code that we have seen and making it very clear what we will be looking for when the consumer legislation is debated. The draft code contains a number of important provisions which implement recommendations of the Trade Practices Commission inquiry into life insurance and superannuation. They require a needs analysis to be formed before a sale is made, a record of customer advice to be kept and various matters to be disclosed, including the method by which life agents are remunerated. This last provision backs away from the TPC recommendation that agents' fees and commissions be disclosed, but it is nevertheless an important step forward. The competency of life insurance intermediaries is also to be dealt with by a system of records and references and there is a requirement that they demonstrate basic knowledge and skills. Finally, the code sets out the conditions to be met by internal and external complaints handling mechanisms.

Clearly, the extent to which the life insurance industry lifts its game depends in large part on the strength of the external complaints handling mechanism. The draft code spells out criteria by which the Insurance and Superannuation Commission must judge the adequacy of external mechanisms, but they are far too vague for comfort. For example, an external complaints system must be `independent of the parties to the complaint', but that is not specific enough to judge whether the existing industry scheme, the Life Insurance Complaints Board, would qualify. This is a matter of some concern, given that the Access to Justice Advisory Committee found that the board `would be unlikely to comply with standards relating to independence from the industry'.

The draft code also requires that the scheme be `effectively promoted'. What does this mean? In the case of telecommunications, the Democrats obtained a ministerial undertaking that every phone customer receive a customer charter telling them, among other things, that they can lodge complaints with the Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman. Should not information of this kind be part of every life insurance policy package? Surely that should be one requirement of the code. I do not believe parliament can give proper consideration to a code which leaves important questions like this unanswered in any way.

A concern which has been put by the consumer movement is that a system which looks fine on paper will fail to work if real resources are not put into monitoring and enforcement. I understand that the Insurance and Superannuation Commission intends putting minimal resources into checking the extent to which life companies comply with the code. Overseas experience suggests that the results of a hands-off approach could well be widespread ignorance and non-compliance amongst intermediaries. Signals have also been sent out that the ISC's intention is to prosecute only as an absolute last resort. Again, my advice is that this approach did not work in the United Kingdom and that a more aggressively regulatory approach has now had to be taken.

I finish by repeating that, while we support the bill, we look forward with some concern to the consumer provisions which were to have formed part of this package. I take this opportunity to ask the parliamentary secretary: can he advise what the government's timetable is; when will we see at least that confidential draft; and when will legislation be before this place? We do really need to see far more commitment to detail and a commitment to more regulatory processes than we have seen so far in the rough draft.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Amendment Bill 1994 amends the Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Act 1992. It seeks to clarify that the act is not to apply in a way which would exceed the Commonwealth's power and provides for the exemption of various types of tobacco advertisements from the operation of the act. The opposition will be not opposing this bill but, in doing so, I would like to record something of the history of the bill and also some criticism of the timing of the bill.

PARA.TAB: The legislation imposing restrictions on the marketing and promotion of tobacco products has been progressively enacted in both the Commonwealth and state spheres since 1976. The first legislative restriction on the promotion of tobacco products was the 1976 amendment to the Broadcasting Act 1942. This introduced a prohibition on the broadcasting on radio and television of advertisements for tobacco products, except as an accident or incidental accompaniment to other matter.

This broadcasting prohibition, while appearing, prima facie, to prevent tobacco advertising on television, in fact did not do so. The exemption for accidental or incidental advertising enabled the continuation of the broadcasting of events such as the Benson and Hedges World Series Cricket, the Winfield Cup and the arts, without infringing the prohibition, and provided an effective loophole through which tobacco companies were able to achieve significant exposure by increasing their sponsorship funding of sport.

From that time onwards various enactments of legislation have ensued, culminating most recently in the Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Act which was enacted on 24 December 1992 and which prohibited the broadcast or publication, knowingly or recklessly, of tobacco advertisements after 1 July 1993. That brings us to the present.

The timing of this legislation, the Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Amendment Bill, has been brought about by the Philip Morris case. The bill amounts to a recognition of the possible invalidity of the act as presently drafted. The passing of the amendments will not stop the Philip Morris challenge of the Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Act as a whole.

The challenge focuses on the right of the industry to communicate on political and government matters and to engage in many ordinary business communications. The legislation will enable companies to legitimately use their corporate logo, communicate on political and government matters, engage in many ordinary corporate communications and undertake activities such as a court imposed recall of a defective product.

This challenge was instituted on 6 June 1994: Philip Morris Ltd instituted an action in the High Court challenging the constitutional validity of the Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Act. One of its grounds was that it was beyond the legislative power of the Commonwealth, for example, that a law which prohibits traders from advertising their tobacco products is not a law with respect to trading corporations.

The present bill cleans up a raft of unintended consequences as a result of poor consultation—and there was very little consultation—and, importantly, poor drafting. It also is a consequence of the speedy passage of the 1992 act. The opposition wants to have this on record: if more adequate prior consultation and better drafting had occurred in the development of that act, it would not be necessary now for this bill to be before the Senate.

In conclusion, I would state that we do not oppose this bill, but we believe that there should have been better drafting and more consultation. It would not have been necessary then for us to be sitting this day to consider this legislation.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is no secret that the Australian Democrats have not been happy with the state of tobacco advertising in this country. We have a long tradition of parliamentary action against the advertising of tobacco products, not the least being our achievement of the historic passing of Senator Janet Powell's private senator's bill in 1989 which banned cigarette advertising in the print media.

PARA.TAB: It also is no secret that the Democrats, along with many others, believe that cigarette smoking is the largest cause of preventable illness in Australia and that the use of tobacco products continues to constitute a huge drain on this country's resources, both human as well as financial. We are firmly of the belief that there is no safe level of tobacco consumption.

Our parliamentary actions have been primarily directed towards ensuring that governments should take all possible steps to prohibit the use of tobacco products. The most recent actions taken by the Democrats include the introduction last year of my private senator's bill and also the establishment of a Senate inquiry into the tobacco industry. That inquiry is now well under way and, in accordance with the terms of reference that I moved last year, the community affairs committee is looking into two crucial areas: firstly, the current level of regulation covering the manufacture, advertising, promotion and sale of tobacco products; and, secondly, the costs of tobacco related illness to the Australian community and a review of existing mechanisms for recouping those costs.

I will not go into what the committee has been doing in any great detail, except to say that submissions already received and in many cases released have come from a range of leading health organisations as well as the tobacco companies. There have been submissions from tobacco growers, health workers and many individuals who are concerned about this issue, including those in the research area.

Perhaps one of the most interesting pieces of evidence to come forward has been about the tobacco companies' push into Asia and the Pacific. Now that they find themselves heavily regulated and beginning to lose their market penetration in Australia, they are moving to target our neighbours; they are targeting them in the way they are not allowed to do here. In some of those countries, the number of young people and children taking up smoking is truly staggering; that will have a huge impact on health costs in those countries.

What Australia can actually do about that is something, no doubt, the committee itself will be deliberating on and discussing. But surely, at the very least, we should be setting an example in this area; we should be setting the lead in our immediate region by getting as tough as we possibly can on the advertising of cigarette products within our own boarders. There has been generally, I think, a very constructive and cooperative approach by all parties to the Senate inquiry. That does lead us to be reasonably confident that we will see, out of this, additional regulation on the advertising of tobacco products in this country.

The reason why we are not moving any of the dozens of amendments that I am sure the Democrats and many others believe now need to be moved is that we believe we should wait for this committee to report. We accept the assurances from the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) that she will look, in detail and at length, at what we do recommend when the report comes down later this year; that this report simply will not be shelved; and that we will be seeing a tightening up to make sure that there are no longer any loopholes or open doors whatsoever.

We need, obviously, to look at a whole range of other issues, including some of the new ways by which tobacco companies are promoting their products, such as give-aways and inducements—particularly for very young children—such as the collection of very attractive presents and bonuses if they buy or subscribe in any way to tobacco products or any material put out by tobacco companies. We have to prevent young people from becoming the targets of cigarette advertising.

We need to make sure that tobacco companies are not able to get around the intent of legislation that has been brought into this place time and time again. We need legislation that is very clear and not open to challenge—and I acknowledge the role of this piece of legislation we have before us today—which ensures that no tobacco advertising means no tobacco advertising; that we do not have in place any mechanisms whatsoever that can be used by companies to get around that and, in particular, target young people.

As I said, we have to ensure that people understand that there is no safe level or form of tobacco use. Indeed, it is time to reject claims that advertising is actually targeted at encouraging people to maintain brand loyalty or switch brands rather than take up smoking in the first place. I conclude by saying that I am confident that the Senate inquiry into the tobacco industry will result in a strong and definitive report and that we will see some very tough recommendations.

SPEECH.PARA: The government has brought on this Procedure Committee report for debate principally to obtain the Senate's agreement to recommendations relating to the presentation of documents and debate by leave. The most civilised way that we have to get senators here on time is by calling a quorum.

It should be noted that committee reports can be debated on Wednesday and Thursday mornings, and further time is available on Thursday afternoons should senators wish to continue their remarks. The government supports the committee's proposal because it provides greater programming certainty, it allows adequate time for consideration of documents when they are tabled and it provides flexibility because, if several documents are presented, arrangements can be made by agreement in advance about the allocation of those documents.

I also think this will allow us to consider prioritising the debate about which documents come up and so on. I have certainly been in here on a number of occasions when senators wanted to take note of certain reports and documents, yet it has not been sorted out which report four senators want to speak on, as apart from one that somebody wants to make only some brief remarks on. Certainly, I believe that any assistance to help organise priorities in this place is to be encouraged.
