TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) has moved a motion which is, as she has said, in accordance with the recommendation of the Procedure Committee. This recommendation arose as a result of a reference to the committee by the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Faulkner). The matter has been considered and this recommendation is now before the chamber. The question is whether the chamber should adopt the recommendation.

PARA.TAB: The attitude on this side of the chamber to these procedural matters has always been that it is up to each individual senator to make up his or her mind. We do not ply a whip to matters of procedure. No doubt the government does because it plies whips to any matter. Our concern is that this is a just a further restraint on the opportunities for senators to contribute to debate. It fits into the pattern of a whole series of so-called reforms that the government and the Australian Democrats have developed over years.

TALK.START.PARA: —You do not need a parliament in a one party state.

—We know the attitude of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to this chamber. He does not actually believe in accountability to the parliament. He regards this chamber as a nuisance which he has to put up with. We actually have a different view. We believe that government should be responsible to both chambers of the parliament. Because he has the numbers in the other place, the House of Representatives cannot assume the responsibility of accountability. The only chamber within the Australian parliament that in any way attempts to keep a government responsible is this chamber. To do so senators have to have time for debate.

PARA.TAB: If the standing orders are to be constantly amended in a way to further restrict the opportunity for senators to contribute and restrict their speaking times, then the capacity for the Senate to hold a government accountable is therefore obviously further limited. That is what concerns us about the deal between the government and the Australian Democrats to further restrict the opportunity and time for each and every senator to contribute in a debate.

If we go through recent history, we recall that under this deal they cut back the time limits for matters of public importance and matters of urgency from two hours to one hour. They cut back the time for the adjournment debate. They also cut back the speaking time in ordinary debates. It is a trend that has been apparent for some time. The attitude of the Australian Democrats is that, if an argument cannot be put in less time, then it is not worth putting. That completely overlooks the development of an argument. We find that unacceptable.

There are two parts to this proposal. There is no doubt that some of the documents introduced in this chamber are of vital importance. If we adopt this proposal, what we are saying is that no senator shall speak for more than 10 minutes and the debate should not continue for more than 30 minutes. Basically, what is being said is that if each senator speaks for the full time, only three senators will have the opportunity to contribute. I suppose if we had a strict rotation on party size, the Australian Democrats, the Greens and Senator Harradine would never have an opportunity to contribute in any debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens will get leave.

—That is right. Exceptions always have to be made for the minority parties. The government will always make an exception for the minorities because it knows it will want their votes when the time comes. It is the opposition that suffers.

PARA.TAB: Why is this necessary? Has the case for restricting speaking time in debates on documents to no more than 10 minutes been made? There was been no attempt on the part of the minister to make out that case today. What is the argument in favour of saying that senators cannot speak for longer than 10 minutes on a matter that might be of vital national importance? What is the argument for saying that, within a whole program, debate on a document should be limited to 30 minutes no matter how important that document might be? Again the case has not been made out.

Where should the onus lie? We say that the Senate should start with the principle of freedom of speech and opportunity to contribute. Those who want to further restrict that should have the onus upon them to make out their argument. No attempt has been made to do so in this instance. Therefore, speaking for myself, although I am pleased that the issue has been brought before the chamber—that is why I am a party to the Procedure Committee's report—I will not support it because I believe senators should have the opportunity to make a full contribution to matters of importance, and debate about documents can be matters of importance. I will not support it because I do not think a debate that is limited to the possibility of just three speakers in a chamber of 76 is giving senators an adequate—

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the opposition not supporting this, or just you?
—Me. If you had listened earlier, you would have heard me say that we do not have a whip on these things.
—I came in late. I am sorry, Senator.

—You might have a government position, but we do not have an opposition position. I think that it is another step in the wrong direction for this chamber. I think this chamber should be looking at its responsibility from the other direction and looking for ways in which individual senators can have a greater opportunity to contribute and less restrictions upon their speaking time. Debates on matters of importance, such as government documents, should be less limited than they are at the moment.

PARA.TAB: Before I sit down, I make my usual plea to the Australian Democrats, who used to say that they came here to keep the bastards honest, that each time they curtail a senator, they restrict the capacity of this chamber to complete its responsibility and accountability. Why they always side with the government to further restrict the rights of senators to contribute in this place, I do not understand. What I am sure of is that they will do it again today. They will join with the government again today and agree that it is unnecessary for senators to speak for any longer than 10 minutes and they will agree that it is unnecessary that there be debate on any document for more than 30 minutes. Therefore, as a result of the passage of this motion, the right of senators to contribute will be further restricted.

That will be their contribution to the chamber today. I think that is a great pity. I am sorry that the Australian Democrats have now moved so far from their original purpose. We are all very confused as to what is their role in the Australian parliament and political process today, other than that it seems to be to continually side with the government and continually be party to the government's program. That is all we can really see as their role.

TALK.START.PARA: —They recognise quality and justice.

—You confirm the very close bond that has been built up between the Australian Democrats and the ALP. I am pleased to hear that. Senator Bourne does not have to hide in this debate. Senator Kernot comes in here each day and urges the ALP to put up taxes. The ALP has announced to the Australian people that it is going to put up taxes. It has become one big happy family.

PARA.TAB: It is not surprising that the Democrats give you notice of every question they ask in questions without notice and that they give you time to have your bureaucrats go and write answers for you. Then they come in here and try to argue that they play out some independent role. It is a load of nonsense.

I concede that in times past the Democrats, particularly under former Senator Chipp, did try to play something of an independent role; they did try to be something of a balance between the major parties; and they did argue that there was a role for Independents or minorities to play that function. But, in recent years, as they have become closer and closer to the ALP—so much so that they are now being referred to as just another faction, the fourth faction or the far left faction of the ALP—their purpose as an independent political body has been lost.

It is not surprising that we will hear from the Australian Democrats that they will again join with the government and further restrict the right of the coalition to come in here and take the government on. They do not want to take the government on. They do not particularly want to see us taking the government on either. It is a matter of regret that I suspect the conspiracy of numbers in this place will be against me and my colleagues who want to vote the same way on this matter and that we will lose again, which will be a loss to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you very much, Madam Acting Deputy President, for letting us listen to Senator Hill yet again turn on the tape. He went into automatic, Democrat mashing mode. It is not even the end of the year. It is right at the beginning of the year. This is getting very sad. Is that all you can talk about?

PARA.TAB: I look forward to the day—I am sure opposition senators do too—when the opposition is in government and Senator Hill gets up and gives that same speech, as I am sure he will. He will say, `Look, the Democrats are again trying to help with the business of this chamber; the Democrats are again trying to make sure that the government gets a fair go in getting its business up.' If the opposition ever gets into government—at this rate, it will not—we will help it to get more government business up because that is a very good idea.

Let me make a point about the second report of the Procedure Committee. I am glad that Senator Hill said that he has his name on it, because he does. So do several other opposition senators who I will not name because it would be too embarrassing for them. This is a unanimous report. I remember sitting in the Procedure Committee meetings and going through the government's motion very carefully. We decided that it was not reasonable. The opposition, however, had some compromise ideas which it put up. They were very good ideas and, if I recall correctly, this is one of them. This is a very good compromise motion which, if I remember correctly, came from an opposition member.

Because it is a compromise motion, because it is not the government's original motion, which would not have been particularly fair, because it is not exactly what the opposition wanted, because it is not exactly what we wanted, and because it is not exactly what the Independents wanted, we will have to come up with a compromise. That compromise will have to stand. It is that or it is something unfair in one direction or another. In the end, I hope we will end up with this one. I do not know whether or not we will because I do not know who will vote for it or against it. I know that we will be voting for it.

Opposition senators may remember 2 February 1994, a very interesting date with respect to procedure in this chamber. That was the day we adopted new sessional orders. Opposition senators might remember them. Then again they might not because they never listen to a word I am saying. They talk amongst themselves. They did not listen at the time, did they? We had a debate on how standing orders should be changed. We decided to do it under sessional orders. During that debate, this whole argument was raised. We debated extensively in the Procedure Committee the changes to sessional orders. Those who were on the Procedure Committee will remember this. Before 2 February 1994 the committee came up with a unanimous decision which was put up in the Procedure Committee report. You can go back and look at it.

The committee addressed what the time limits for debates on government documents ought to be. We came up with a sessional order which gave us an hour on Tuesdays, an hour on Wednesdays and an hour and a half on Thursdays. That was supposed to apply to debates on documents, but that has not happened. Documents come in by leave and documents come in at other times. This is loophole that everybody agreed should be looked at. We did not all agree that it should be changed; we just agreed that it should be looked at. A lot of us agreed that it should be changed. The Procedure Committee came up with this compromise change to sessional orders which would close that loophole.

The Procedure Committee also said that we should review the operation of this provision early next year. I am sure all senators will agree that the changed sessional orders are not working in all ways. We have to look at how they can be changed. This is one of the most urgent things that need to be changed. It is not working the way it was supposed to work and the way we agreed it would work on 2 February 1994. After a year of trying it out, it is not doing what we agreed it should do in that Procedure Committee report before 2 February 1994.

We will be voting for this. Opposition senators say, `What a surprise! The Democrats will be voting for something that came up in the Procedure Committee. My goodness me! They agreed to this in the Procedure Committee. They went through the debate. They agreed with it, as did everybody else in the Procedure Committee, and now they're going to vote for it. Good Lord!' I will be really interested to see which opposition senators—of course, they have no whip on this so they will not vote the same way, unless they are all terribly in agreement with Senator Hill—vote which way. They will not be crossing the floor, of course; they will all be voting for exactly what they believe in! It will be really interesting to see how their arguments and their votes today reconcile with their arguments and their votes in the Procedure Committee. I will be looking forward to that happening in a very short time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to indicate support for the motion moved by the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley).
—Of course you would.

—Of course I would because I happen to be a member of the Procedure Committee. Senator Bourne gave an accurate rendition of the events at that committee. Senator Hill never ceases to amaze me. I do not know why he bothers being a member of the Procedure Committee or having other opposition members on it. They debate matters, come to an agreement and the motion is put up, but when it gets in here they vote against it. The `one big happy family' that he talked about was the one big happy family of the Procedure Committee, which came to a reasonable agreement about what should be put up.

PARA.TAB: In addition to the arguments that the minister put forward, I would like to indicate an additional argument about fairness. It has nothing to do with fairness between the opposition and the government or the minor parties. It relates to the way in which documents are dealt with. Under standing orders, rules apply to documents which are tabled in the normal course of events. Under standing orders, senators have five minutes in some cases and 10 minutes in others in which to make their speeches. The unfairness arises when documents happen to be presented to the President during a non-sitting period and are then tabled in here by the President. They get treated differently, in that half-hour speeches are able to be given and there is no overall time limit.

Someone who wants to speak on a document which has been tabled in that way—it is all accidental—is advantaged. Those documents that are tabled in the normal course of events on a sitting day get treated differently. I do not think that is a fair way of dealing with things. That especially applies to the question of people wanting to encourage documents to be made available to the parliament as soon as possible. That is why we introduced the method by which documents—whether they be from the Auditor-General, ministers or committees—can be presented to the President during a non-sitting period and then formally tabled once the Senate meets again.

I would have thought that everyone would think that a reasonable way to go. But, if this proposal gets defeated, it means that there is an encouragement for committees and ministers to wait until the Senate meets again before tabling documents. I would have thought that the whole process goes hand in hand with a procedure which enables documents to be made public, presented to the President as soon as possible but, once the Senate meets again, tabled in here. On that basis, I think it is a very reasonable proposal, which the opposition members of the procedure committee agree with. I hope that everyone in this chamber agrees with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —This argument is really about the rights of the parliament and nothing else. I listened very carefully to the speakers in this debate. With the greatest respect to him, the previous speaker talked nonsense. The speaker before him gave the typical Australian Democrats line. Until this debate started, I had no knowledge of how Senator Hill was going to vote on it. I have no knowledge of how any of my colleagues on this side are going to vote. We have not caucused it or raised it in the party room, because we always follow the tradition that, in matters of procedure, how we vote is a matter of individual judgment. I am confident of the intelligence, experience and probity of my colleagues. They will see that the standards of this parliament are upheld. I return to the point I started with: we are talking about the rights of the parliament.

PARA.TAB: We need to enunciate a couple of basic rights. One right that was violated most enormously last week by a supine, cowardly government is the right of access of parliamentarians and the public to the parliament. This government allowed this parliament to be ransomed by a bunch of strikers or protesters, who blocked access to this place. I do not mind protests, but I do mind very much when the access roads to the parliament are blocked, as they were then with big trucks.

There is a community of over 3,000 people in this building through the working week. Any of them, particularly some members of the government, could have easily succumbed to a heart attack. There could have been any sort of accident in this building—there could have been a fire—in which case help could not have been brought to this building. There would have been a delay of at least half an hour, because the drivers of those trucks were often nowhere in sight. So there is a practical element to the principle of freedom of access to this building by parliamentarians and the public.

Another great principle about parliamentary democracy is freedom of speech. It involves the unqualified right to debate whatever we like in this place. That basic freedom is assailed by the proposition which is before us today.

Despite what the Democrats might think, the great fight in this building is not between the Liberal Party and the Labor Party; the fight is fundamentally between the executive government—the ministry—and the parliament. The basic point we make, and have always made, of the democratic system is that the executive government is answerable to the parliament.

Only a fool would believe that the executive government volunteers information. The executive government of any political persuasion has to have information dragged out of it. It is the ability of the parliament to have access to that executive which keeps the executive government honest. If we do not have that, we have a dishonest and disintegrating government and a disintegrating democratic system. There is a very fundamental, important reason as to why the executive should be able to be examined. So many of the reports that come before this parliament in some way or other deal with the executive government's actions. So any abrogation of that right to debate those reports is a sanctuary for the executive government to shelter in.

I can understand the Democrats being in collusion with the Labor Party. I look forward to the time when we get into government in a few months, when the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) calls the election, because we will see the disintegration of the Labor Party as we know it. It has cut itself off from its union base very effectively. A new party will be formed out of the mad Left and the Democrats and some residue in the Labor Party. But that is all for the future.

I want to say this as a senior opposition senator: in my time here I know of no group of individuals that has assaulted the institution of the parliament more than the Democrats. They have a total lack of principle and policies and demonstrate rank opportunism. They have assaulted the institution of parliament in a way that no other party or group has done since Federation. We have seen the further mindless exercise of that today.

I now come to the limitation of time on the debating of reports. This parliament, in either the House of Representatives or the Senate, commissions a number of reports either through standing committees, statutory committees or select committees. In addition, we get reports from government statutory authorities. All of those reports that are set out are to provide information to the parliament.

Some of the committees that we have set up in this Senate alone would have cost many hundreds of thousands of dollars to see through to completion. It would be very interesting to do an audit on what the committee system actually costs the parliament in bringing witnesses before committees, holding hearings and printing reports. It is no exaggeration to say that, in the case of big inquiries, it would run into hundreds of thousands of dollars. Their reports should be debated in the parliament, because the parliament has commissioned them for knowledge. We now have a situation being foisted upon us by these non-democratic people, who have no understanding of what the parliament is about, that will deny the opportunity for the parliament to debate those reports.

Because Senator Schacht does not understand, I will give an example. One of the biggest reports to come before this parliament in the last month and a half of sitting time was the defence white paper, which came in around 10 December. That is a fundamentally important document for Australia. The time for its debate was really very restricted under the existing system. Under the system that the government wants to impose on us, there would be one speaker from the Labor Party for 10 minutes, one from the Liberal Party and one from the National Party in the entire debate. It is a paper which affects Australia's defence capabilities for the next 10 or 15 years. Such examples are legion. Many reports in that category should be debated.

All we hear from the Labor Party is some whining about how if it allows us to keep on going in the way we have, which has been the practice for a very long time, we will find that it cannot predict its program. I have news for the Labor Party. We do not run the Senate or the House of Representatives purely for the convenience of the Labor Party; we run it for the people of Australia and their interests.

In the time that I have been here, I have seen speaking rights abridged enormously. When I first came into this chamber, every senator could speak for one hour on every bill. We are now back to 20 minutes, which is one-third of the original time we had. We had the opportunity to speak on the first reading of a money bill. That has now disappeared. We had one hour to speak on the adjournment to raise matters that concerned us. It was then cut back to 30 minutes. It is now back to 10 minutes per speech for a total time of 40 minutes per night. It is an absolute absurdity on what it was before.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the quality has improved considerably.

—I do not think it has. The quality is not the key. I was bored witless year after year while a fellow who was known by Senator Schacht's own party as `Feathers' McLaren railed about the rent that Doug Anthony was paying for his house in Canberra. Night after night the same thing came out. No thinking person could agree that the quality now is worse than when the Labor Party was in opposition. That is a delusion of a magnitude I could not encompass.

PARA.TAB: I return to the point that the opportunities in the parliament have been greatly circumscribed. We have seen a run-down in the government's ability to govern as a consequence. The newspapers say that we need a good opposition to have a good government. I do not care how good the opposition is; there will never be a good government when a Labor government is in power. But when we are denied the right to inquire and criticise the government, as the Democrats and the Labor Party have increasingly moved against us, the ability to be an effective opposition is very much circumscribed. As Senator Hill said, it is all part of a pattern to reduce the power of the chamber to go down the path of the one-party state.

The answer to all of these problems, if they are real, is it to extend the sitting year. I have always maintained that the sitting time for the Senate was far too short. Since the Labor Party has been in power we have seen the sitting year shortened compared to what it was in the time when we were in government, which I thought was too short. We used to sit in those days for three sitting weeks and then have one week in recess. We sat for three days a week. So we had nine sitting days per month. Nowadays we have two weeks on and two weeks off and we sit for four days a week. We have eight sitting days per month. We have lost a day there. Everywhere you look the evidence is overwhelming that the sitting year of the parliament should be extended so that we do the things that we are elected to do and become professionals in our job, not just mere ciphers for whatever caucus might decide. I trenchantly oppose this motion.

That the motion (Senator Crowley's) be agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate may or may not recall that in 1989 I brought a private member's bill to the Senate regarding an end of war list for the Vietnam veterans. It followed some six months of petition and debate in the House. The Senate may remember that it was also a time of great momentum for the recognition of the Vietnam veterans, led by the 1987 coming home parade, a very moving event, and the beginnings of the establishment of the war memorial, or shrine, for the Vietnam veterans in Anzac Parade, which I believe was finally opened in 1992.

PARA.TAB: The catalyst for my own endeavours was the story of the 23-year-old Second Lieutenant John Fraser. John Fraser is symbolic of the many unsung heroes of the Vietnam War, this controversial war. It should be noted that my private member's bill was never a comment on the war itself. It did not take either side of this controversial war but rather the side of those who served in the war.

Just briefly, the story of John Fraser is that he was killed on 26 March 1968 when he deliberately kept both feet on an activated mine, a jumping jack mine, to give his platoon time to take cover. That is the short version of John Fraser's heroic act. It seemed right to me at the time to establish a tribunal to review the acts of bravery that were overlooked and that were deserving of recognition in this war—that if there was one such unsung hero as John Fraser there could well be more.

The people of the Gold Coast, let alone John Fraser's family, have not forgotten John Fraser and his giving up his life for his country. The people of the Gold Coast and Surfers Paradise have established a park in the heart of Surfers Paradise dedicated to his memory. But it seems the defence department has forgotten John Fraser. This has brought great hurt to his family.

In an invitation by the defence department to Vietnam veterans that there may be some back pay and that they should apply for it, his family did so, be it that there was no back pay deserving to John Fraser. The hurt came by the fact that the defence department wrote back to John Fraser himself and not to the author of the letter, which happened to be his brother Fred. This callous bureaucratic error brought hurt to Fred and his family. The Brisbane Sunday Mail described it as `The Canberra bureaucracy is heartless and bungling.'

It could be that the department may well claim an honest mistake, but it is at the very least a highly careless mistake. The bureaucrats should never lose sight of the fact that they are dealing with people, not procedures and regulations. Every single letter they send out is to a person and it is important. I ask the minister to address this error and express regret so the family's hurt does not continue for a day longer. They believe that the defence department has not recognised the death of their son and brother, John Fraser, let alone his heroic act, which was many times brought before the Senate.

The defence department has acted in a typically bureaucratic way. It has written a standard letter back to a man who died over 23 years ago. It does not even have on the record that this man died for the country and that he has passed away. Obviously the department did not even read the letter that Fred Fraser had sent. You would have thought it was a simple procedure simply to write back to the author of the letter. Instead, the department wrote back to the dead John Fraser.

The family cannot see past the fact that their lost son and brother died while serving their country. At the very least, the defence department should have had this on record. One would have to wonder how many times this has happened before—how many others have written to the defence department taking up its invitation for back pay in the Vietnam War and received the same callous and at least careless reply from the defence department.

If the minister or the head of the defence department can send a letter of regret, it will signal that the system has some feeling in it and accepts the consequences of its mistake. If not, the very cold and callous opposite will be true. I am sure the minister in the chamber would agree that we in public life should never forget that no letter or person should be too small to attend to with the respect that everyone in this country deserves.

TALK.START.PARA: — I would like to take the opportunity tonight to say something of the shambles our superannuation arrangements are in. I support the use of superannuation. Ideally, it should be part of our personal planning for retirement, but at the very least it is now part of the award system which catches almost everybody. Presently, of course, that award system is employer funded. The government is looking at the possibility that it be contributed to by employees, and the coalition has indicated that it will look very favourably at that suggestion when it comes forward.

PARA.TAB: A massive amount of money is involved, and it is money that is of great economic significance to our economic system. I have been dismayed that it has been indicated in recent surveys that there is a massive collapse in consumer confidence in superannuation. I guess we all have anecdotal examples of that. Frankly, I do not understand the way our superannuation system works, and I am sure the great majority of average Australian workers do not either.

A recent survey by the Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations found that 75 per cent of superannuants did not have enough information to understand how the compulsory superannuation system worked. The survey results, which were used as the basis of a report by the Australian Consumers Council, found that more than 50 per cent of people believed superannuation was a bad investment, while 43 per cent felt they had little control of or access to their money. This is in a nation where we have a chronic problem with not encouraging enough savings. We need to do that so that we can have a greater percentage of home-grown investment, which has flow-on effects in controlling our foreign debt and other things.

More than one-fifth of the respondents said they had difficulty moving money between funds. Sixty per cent said they could not understand the correspondence from their funds. I think we can all sympathise and empathise with that. It is no wonder they feel this way. Over the last number of years, on average there has been a change to the superannuation act every 28 days. Financial advisers and experts, let alone the average person, would have trouble keeping up with this uncertainty. Small employers, like me, have no confidence in the way that the superannuation funds work either. Quite clearly, fund fees and tax are white-anting the futures of all working people, where there is an all party agreement that super is vital to a rapidly ageing Australian population.

The current failure of the Treasurer, Mr Willis, to rule out further tax rises on superannuation proves that Labor sees retirement savings as a convenient milch cow. Since 1983 this government has increased the tax on superannuation by nearly 900 per cent, with revenue increasing from $7 million to $1.5 billion last financial year. Since the 1993 election, the tax advantage on a superannuation investment of $1,000 has been reduced from $230 to $190. On top of this, most funds have had a disastrous last 12 months—many of them returning losses.

To put it simply, any further reduction in returns from extra tax imposts will significantly undermine people's willingness to invest in long-term savings. Raising superannuation taxes means that the benefits to the employee are reduced, forcing a greater percentage of the population onto the age pension. As I have said, with a rapidly ageing population that is something which must not be encouraged. This plainly contradicts the government's claim that its strategy is to reduce dependence on the public purse. The coalition has firmly committed itself to not increasing the tax burden on superannuation funds in retirement. The government has failed to do this—in fact, it has indicated the opposite.

Another aspect that deeply concerns me is the government's inaction on small amounts protection for casual employees. There are lots of examples of this. Anybody involved in paying casual employees, like shearers, would be aware of the complexity and the lack of certainty. You feel as though you are writing a cheque to the benefit of somebody who has earned it, has worked hard for it, but you have very little confidence that at the end of the day it will be properly accounted to for that person. The system does not work very well because, after you have written a cheque to the superannuation fund, frequently in the next 12 months you get asked by the employee, `Have you done it? What has happened to the money?' There is no confidence from the employer's point of view and certainly no confidence from the employee's point of view either.

Clearly, where these small funds are held by superannuation companies, the administration charges eat up the value very quickly. At the end of the day people could be paying superannuation companies for the benefit of their having had their money invested over a period of years where people have not been in compulsory superannuation schemes for very long.

I float this suggestion: one body, one organisation, in the country has absolute records on all taxpayers. It has the tax file number. I refer to the Australian Taxation Office. I note that from 1 July it will administer small funds deposited with it. As an employer who pays the PAYE component of an employee wage or salary, I can say it would be very simple for the superannuation guarantee levy to be paid and administered in the same way. A number of options could take place in the way the Australian Taxation Office wants to administer those funds. This idea has some merit because the Australian Taxation Office is the one organisation that has a complete record of Australian taxpayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Over the weekend we had the extraordinary spectacle of the government finally admitting what we have been telling it for months and months: the budget deficit is out of control and it must reduce its own spending if it is to bring the deficit into order. It was a classical example of why this government is simply not believed anymore, why this government has absolutely no credibility in the Australian community.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has been telling us for months and months that expenditure has been cut to the bone, that there is no room left to save any money, and dropping all these hints about tax increases. Then we had the spectacle of the Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley) telling us completely the opposite: that there is plenty of room to make big cuts, that the government will all of a sudden decide to target its spending to where it is needed and that, look out, here it comes—the government will be cutting into its spending. The government now looks absolutely stupid, with all the Prime Minister's rhetoric being completely contradicted by his own Minister for Finance. Mr Beazley is now the most famous deficit dalek of them all.

As a result of what has happened, today I asked the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) whether she was still prepared to support her policy of giving child-care assistance to millionaires. The minister, unusually, refused this time, having been asked about this policy ever since it was introduced, to endorse her own policy. She backed off with the camouflage that she was not prepared to discuss things that might be in the budget. This is an existing policy. This is being paid out today and every day to anybody who wants it and qualifies regardless of their income or their means. The minister refuses to endorse the policy because she knows that she is about to be rolled on this issue. It is quite clear that the government has finally woken up and knows that this policy must be changed and will be changed.

Minister Crowley will be absolutely humiliated in relation to this issue. She knows that that policy should have been brought in on the basis of means testing, that she should have accepted the coalition's amendments to the proposal to provide for means testing of this benefit and that this government and this country cannot afford and should not be providing these sorts of measures for millionaires and very high income earners. The minister's policy of not means testing the child-care rebate is absolutely irresponsible. It was nothing more than an election bribe made in the passionate heat of the 1993 election campaign.

It is worth looking at the history of this measure. Labor ministers going way back have resisted all the urging from within the Public Service to bring in this measure. Peter Walsh was the most best-known defender of sanity and responsible policy in this area, having tried to stop the government succumbing to the pleadings of the special interest groups, particularly the Public Service. This is a classic case of a government which is making policy of the Public Service, by the Public Service, for the Public Service. When a government succumbs to that, you know it is finished.

This is a classic case of a policy that has been designed to benefit well-paid public servants and has nothing to do with the constituency, which the Labor Party proclaims to represent. In the Labor Party's desperation in 1993, it made yet another promise which it probably thought it would not have to implement—it could make it irresponsibly and recklessly—but made it in the hope that it might get it over the line.

The coalition, responsibly, did not attempt to match the promise because it knew that it was irresponsible. But, lo and behold, the government found itself back in office with a $150 million a year rope around its neck. The policy is fiscally reckless. The government's budget deficit is out of control. We now have a government which budgets on the basis of asset sales being used in one-off ways to artificially reduce the budget deficit. The government has artificially reduced it this year. Now we see that the Qantas sale will not happen this year. The Financial Review reported today that the government may well not get the money it is expecting for Qantas anyway, so the budget deficit is really in trouble. All of a sudden, these reckless promises which the government made in 1993 are coming back to haunt it.

Not only is this policy of not means testing the child-care rebate reckless and irresponsible; it is also terribly unfair to a significant component of mothers in this country. It completely ignores the position of mothers who sacrifice an income to care for their children at home. I do not think the Labor Party realised this when it introduced this policy and when it promised it in the 1993 campaign. Of course, when it did bring it in, it unleashed a veritable storm across Australia on the part of those mothers who have sacrificed an income to care for their children at home. They suddenly saw their sisters who made the choice of going back into the full-time work force being paid to do so by the government, having all their child-care expenses paid regardless of whether they were earning $100,000, $200,000 or $500,000 a year, while they struggle at home to bring up their children with very little assistance at all.

It is not only the cost; it is a very important matter that, when you make public policy, it must be fair and reasonable and not discriminate against particular groups in the community. The government's argument is—as I was reminded by Mr Keating's words in 1993 on the news tonight—`It is not really welfare; it is a right. It is an expenditure incurred in earning an income.' Simplistically and superficially that may seem the case, but that argument can then be extended to every expenditure which men or women incur in earning an income. Why doesn't it include having the gardening done, the housekeeping done, the ironing done, the dog walked or all the other numerous expenses that occur domestically when you go into the paid work force? It is a nonsensical argument when it is taken to its logical end, and it ignores the fact that it is incredibly unfair, discriminatory and biased against those who choose to care for their children at home. Government policy should not deliberately bias the choice that mothers make as to what their arrangements are going to be with their children.

Many within the Labor movement have recognised this inequity. Martin Ferguson said only yesterday that it was absolutely ridiculous to be paying millionaires for their child care. An unnamed minister is quoted in the Sunday newspapers as saying that it was nonsensical. The shop assistants union moved a motion in Senator Crowley's own home state to bring in a means test on this benefit. The minister and the government have got themselves in an awful bind. They are about to break yet another election promise. Not only did we have the l-a-w tax cuts from 1993 that have been broken already, and will be further broken no doubt, but we have yet another election bribe that is going to be broken.

The government has no credibility. I say to the voters of Australia: do not believe anything that this government tells you in the lead-up to the 1995-96 election. There is nothing this government offers you or promises you that you should believe, because this government has no credibility whatsoever. The government should have accepted our amendments when this proposition came in. It should have accepted the coalition point of view that this was fiscally irresponsible. We have been attacked relentlessly by the government for saying that the budget deficit should be reduced, and attacked by it saying that we have not come up with ways of doing it. This is a classic instance of when we did say, `Here is a simple way that you can contain your expenditure—by means testing this benefit.' It would not only have benefits for the budget but benefits of fairness and good public policy. But, again, through the cynical political machinations of the government and its desperation to win an election, it ignored us. Of course, the minister's only defence today was to say, `You voted for it.'

We moved the amendments on the basis that, if the government and the Democrats did not accept our amendments, we would ultimately—but reluctantly—support the bill. The four factions of the Labor Party had the numbers anyway and, of course, if we opposed the bill in toto, no doubt the government would have run around the country attacking us for denying mothers in the paid work force any child-care rebate at all. It is a pathetic defence of the minister to now say, `You on the other side ended up voting for it.' She knows full well we argued passionately and determinedly for this proposal to be means tested, to no avail unfortunately. Now it is coming back to haunt her. I look forward to the government's admitting its mistake; admitting to the Australian people that they were misled and that they were bribed; and admitting that fiscal responsibility is something that the government—unfortunately far too late—will now take seriously.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction, upon notice, on 15 December 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the recent incident where a group of 13 Vietnamese boat people arrived at a boat ramp in suburban Darwin early on 22 November 1994 and flagged down a passing motorist:
(1) Does the Government agree that on this occasion there was a failure to detect a potentially significant and sensitive vessel illegally landing in Australia.
(2) Has there been an independent evaluation of the incident.
(3) Does this incident represent a failure in regard to intelligence and/or an inadequate use of risk analysis techniques.
(4) What agencies are presently involved in intelligence gathering.
(5) What risk techniques are used by Coastwatch, and which other agencies use these techniques.
(6) Is November one of the peak months for illegal vessel activity in Australian waters.
(7) At the time of this incident, was Coastwatch fully operation; if not, why not and to what extent was it operational.
(8) Did the co-operative arrangements with Indonesia fail on this occasion; if so, why and in what way.
(9) With respect to inter-agency communication, were all opportunities for closer liaison and co-operation recognised and taken with respect to this incident.
(10) Have all recommendations from the Suspect Illegal Entrant Vessel (SIEV) investigation been implemented; if not, which have not been implemented and why.
(11) Have all findings from the SIEV investigation been implemented; if not, which have not been implemented and why.
(12) If the recommendations and findings from the report have been implemented, has there been a failure in minimising the recurrence of SIEV landings despite their implementation.

(13) Given this incident, is there a need for a re-examination of SIEV surveillance arrangements and a fresh set of recommendations aimed at preventing, as far as possible, incidents such as this occurring again.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes.

(2) Coastwatch, as a matter of course, conducts a post operation evaluation of all major incidents. Such an evaluation has been completed for this incident. The evaluation was not "independent" in the sense that it was conducted by Coastwatch officers. However, these officers had not been involved in any way in the events leading up to the incident.

(3) Appropriate inter-agency mechanisms are in place to co-ordinate the collection of intelligence concerning vessels potentially seeking to enter Australia illegally. In this case, no intelligence was available to indicate that the vessel was en route to Australia.

(4) The Australian Customs Service; the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs; Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade; Department of Defence; Australian Federal Police; and Australian Quarantine Inspection Service.

(5) Coastwatch surveillance planning is driven by specific surveillance priorities and threat areas identified by client government agencies. The clients submit bids to Coastwatch supporting appropriate levels of aerial and surface surveillance effort, in keeping with the assessed level of threat. The client agencies include the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, the Australian Fisheries Management Authority, the Australian Customs Service, and the Australian Nature Conservation Agency.
(6) No. In the five years prior to 1994 only two other vessels have arrived in the month of November. The first in 1989 and the second in 1993.
(7) Yes. All programmed surveillance tasks were achieved at the time of the incident.

(8) There was no prior information from the Indonesian authorities on the movement of the vessel. Full support was received from the Indonesians when Australia sought to return the passengers to Indonesia.

(9) Commonwealth agencies with a direct interest in suspect illegal entrant vessels were in close liaison at the time of the incident. Close liaison between Coastwatch and its clients is normal practice, and whenever information about possible suspect illegal entry vessels (SIEV) arrivals comes to notice this liaison is intensified.

(10) All recommendations of the Report on the Investigation into Arrival of Suspect Illegal Entrant Vessel (SIEV) into Montague Sound have been implemented. However, in relation to Recommendation No. 5, a Resource Agreement was not established with the Department of Finance. Instead supplementation would be used to augment normal appropriations should the need arise.

(11) All findings of the Report on the Investigation into Arrival of Suspect Illegal Entrant Vessel (SIEV) into Montague Sound which suggested future action or changes of practice have been implemented.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Defence Land at St Marys in Sydney

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, upon notice, on 22 December 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the environmental assessment of a proposal to rezone and sell for housing the former Defence land at St Mary's in western Sydney, now vested by the Commonwealth with Australian Defence Industries (a government business enterprise wholly owned by the Commonwealth):
(1) Is the Minister aware that dillwynia tenuifolia, pultenaea parviflora, minutiflora and

QUESTION.PARA: persoonia nutans, plant species listed under the Endangered Species Protection Act 1992, occur as significant populations on the St Mary's site; if so, will a Commonwealth environmental assessment be conducted as provided for under section 5A of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 to ensure the conservation of these species; if not, why not.

PARA.TAB: (2) Is the Minister aware of the Commonwealth's responsibility to act in cases where species may be threatened by Commonwealth actions, approvals or decisions.
(3) Will action be taken against the development threats at St Mary's site.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) I am aware that an area to the north east of the St Mary's site supports four endangered plant species listed in Schedule 1 to the Endangered Species Protection Act 1992. These are: Persoonia nutans, Dillwynia tenuifolia, Pultenaea parviflora, and Micromyrtus minutiflora.

The Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974, administered by the Environment Protection Agency was triggered in relation to proposals for demolition and decontamination at Australian Defence Industries' St Mary's site in June 1992, before the endangered plants were discovered on the site. In accordance with the Intergovernmental Agreement on the Environment and as the remediation is being undertaken to NSW Environment Protection Authority specifications, the Environment Protection Agency and the NSW Department of Planning agreed that the Commonwealth would use the NSW planning and assessment processes as the primary vehicles for assessing environmental effects. The Environment Protection Agency will build its requirements into the NSW process and will ensure that proper account is taken of possible effects on the endangered species.
(2) Yes.

(3) The Australian Nature Conservation Agency, the Environment Protection Agency and the NSW National Parks and Wildlife Service are currently involved in monitoring and providing advice to Australian Defence Industries on the environmental effects of decontamination procedures. The Australian Heritage Commission has provided advice to Australian Defence Industries with regard to the built environment. The role of my portfolio in relation to further developments on the site will be determined when further specific development proposals are made.
